The decor is clean and simple and they have some really flavorful organic teas.  The combination of flavors of some of their omelettes is great.  The pesto in the Sicilian is perfection with the sun-dried tomatoes, spinach and feta.  (If I weren't Jewish, I would SO be Italian.)  I also like the eponymous Church St. and the 24th St. omelettes. 

However, the egg part of the omelette is always really thin.  It's more like an egg crepe than an omelette.  I don't know if they use two or three eggs, but I'm guessing it's two and I'm also guessing that's a cost-saving decision.   On the plus side, I believe they use cage-free eggs.  Similarly, depending on the day, the Italian sausage is either like the size of my palm or a the size of one finger.   Maybe that's just how Italian sausage is, but I've dated only two Italians so I don't have much of basis for comparison (ba dah bump).  

The prices are reasonable -- most breakfast entrees are $9.75, but where they make up the difference is on the sides, which fare about $3.75.  If you tend to forgo toast and hash browns and need something else on the side to fill you up, the sides add up. 

On weekends, it's easier to get a seat at the Church Street location.  Twenty-fourth almost always has a wait on Saturdays and Sundays before about 1 pm.

Toast has enough going for it that I will continue to spend money here.  It may be a better value for those who eat more simple carbs -- ya know, like toast.
author: Ms C.

description:
I would've given this place 3 maybe 4 stars, but the customer service brings that rating down to 2 stars.  We have been here a few times and the food is ok, tasty hash browns, fries and grilled sandwich, but not worth having to put up with a rude manager.
 
Last time we went we got there right before 11am on a Tuesday, so the place was pretty empty.  The waitress told us we could sit anywhere, in fact she pointed at the 4 chair table next to the window.  We are only 2, but decided it was a nice spot, plus there were PLENTY of 4 chair tables open.  Right after we sit down, the manager comes running over to tell us to please move to another table! She mentioned that rush hour was soon and that she might need that table.  Really? rush hour? on a Tuesday? the place was empty! Anyway, we moved tables since we were starving.  About 20 mins later, another couple sits on the same table and she does the same thing! The place is still empty! I dont know what is up with her and that table, but if your customer is sitting down, its just RUDE to ask them to move just because of the possibility of a bigger group needing the table.  I would understand if its crowded, but the place is empty!  What I really liked is that the couple refused to move and she had to serve them there.  Yes, we left about 45 mins later and the place was still empty with plenty of 4 chair tables open!
I doubt we will be coming back, unless we are starving or ordering take out (not sure if they even do that).
author: J B.

description:
Toast is good, more like 3.5 stars than a 3.

    The service is good at Toast, the food consistant and consistantly good, and they make a mean Mimosa.

    The wait can be long because the place is always packed at breakfast, so be prepared to wait outside on 24th street if you come with two or more people.   As a lonely loser, I usually get counter service without a wait.

   For breakfast, I like the Eggs Benedict.  It can be a bit much, but you only live once.  Served with yummy, crispy hash browns.

   For lunch/dinner, I usually get the Hummus sandwich, veggies and sprouts and hummus and avocado served on, get this, toast.  Filling AND healthy.

   I've not been impressed with the Philly Cheese Steak.  Just sayin'.
author: Bad Y.

description:
Came here for the first time this past weekend. Parking can be nutz, but that Noe Valley for ya. I just dropped off my friends while I went to find parking and when i got to the restaurant, they got seats already! YAY! 

I ordered the breakfast sandwich w/ ham, my friend ordered the corn beef hash, and the other one ordered Toast combo with the chicken apple sausage. My friend said his apple sausage was bland, eggs were good, pancakes was alright (nothing special), and the latte was good. My breakfast sandwich was alright - yummy. My other friend said her corn beef hash was good. 

We all agreed that Toast does give you big portions and was worth the price. We all loved the hash browns which was awesomely crispy. 

I would definitely be back, especially for the hash browns.
author: James L.

description: Only went here once, but would go again.  Food was a bit on the pricey side, and despite having toast in its name, the toast was rather subpar; however, the omelet I ordered was rather good and so were the hash browns.  The service was decent as well even though the place was packed for breakfast.
author: Brendan M.

description:
I've got a pretty big weakness for big plates of unhealthy breakfast food, so this place is right up my alley. Can't really comment on the non-breakfast items, but the scramblers and omelets are all fantastic, and all the prices are reasonable.
If you're coming in on the weekends, I highly recommend trying to hit off-peak hours. The wait can be pretty insane in the 10:30AM to 1PM range on Saturday and Sunday.
author: Pat M.

description:
Dear Toast, 
I love your pancakes.

Excellent service,grubbin food, consistent, quality ingredients, reasonable prices and a neighborhood favorite for a reason.  BOTH locations :)

Why are people afraid to wait a little for a good breakfast?  If you're so hungry, try to cook your own grilled cheese so you don't biatch about the price of having to buy one! 

I think the waitresses are all pretty damn good or they probably would be let go already.  Maybe some people missed the memos on the economy. Do you know how many people would kill for a waitressing gig at a popular, consistently busy, worth-the-wait-kinda breakfast joint in SF?

Just because some masterDouche had an isolated bad experience here, Toast rocks.  I go there enough to judge honestly and am mad at myself for not yelping sooner.  Funny how the brain works when you have ADD.  :)
Look people, welcome to life.  And welcome to restaurants.  Screw-ups happen.  Not everyone is on  their A game 100% - are you?  It's HOW the inevitable slip up gets handled and it sounds to me like Toast handled it just fine.  I find it entertaining how the same person who gives a one star gives one stars everywhere.  Smells fishy, ground Chuck D.

I'm going to enjoy Toast Eatery this weekend, maybe I should invite Chuck,  scratch tat. I don't think there will be room at my table for his ego.

I have 2 Toast Tshirts by the by.  I wore one while I was in St Louis and a couple stopped me because of my T.  I don't think it's just the neighborhood that are fans.
author: Athena S.

description:
We come here almost every week for brunch. SUPER QUICK turnover rate - if there's a few tables in front of you, just wait a few minutes. This is probably in part because their waitresses are all closet ninjas.

I judge brunch-makers by their hollandaise. Toast house my favorite hollandaise in the city. Combined with their perfectly-cooked hash browns, that's a killer brunch. Or if you're into something sweet, get their seriously delicious fruit & nutella waffles. Also, don't forget to order a mimosa.

Inexpensive, delicious, & fast. I love you, Toast.
author: Celeste R.

description: Toast, please do better.  You're so ordinary, like a Waffle House in a better environment.  Bring some creativity to the menu.
author: David C.

description:
If Toast, the restaurant, were toast, the food...what kind would it be?

Sourdough.  Very San Francisco, a step up from white bread, tasty, but not too "out there".

This new location looks a lot like the original one on Church, with more room.  Everything about it is clean and organized, including the food.

Imagine that you are at a diner and your food comes out looking exactly like the picture on the menu, instead of a thrown-together, fat-laden, mess.  You'd probably be happy with the healthier choice, but you might kind of miss the greasy spoon taste.  That's how Toast feels to me.

My lovely lunch date Kristina had a scramble, which came with hash browns and toast - it was good.  I had the Chef's Salad with house-made poppy seed dressing.  While I could appreciate the quality of the ingredients (Niman Ranch meats), it was a little bland, and seriously under dressed.  I asked for more dressing and that helped somewhat.  We shared the apple pie for dessert which was just ok.

I think they are doing well, judging by the weekday crowd that was in there the day that we went.  I can see why - it is a reliable choice.  Service was nice, so no issues there.

I like Toast, the restaurant, but just like toast, the food, it's not something that I'll get overly excited about.
author: Liz S.

description:
Wow...this place was so good. I came here for an early brunch on Saturday morning. They have a wide selection of omlettes and pancakes you can choose from.  I ordered the Joe's omlette with some meat and veggies. It was one of the best omlettes I ever had. The hash brown was also good as well. I was surprised it wasn't too packed. I was afraid it would be jam packed on a Saturday morning. 
I did see chocolate covered pancakes with bananas that someone else had ordered. I am definitely gonna try that out next time. 

I was pretty filled after the meal and had no regrets. If you're ever in the San Francisco area, and looking for a good breakfast, brunch or lunch, definitely try out the Toast Eatery.
author: Dave K.

description: American diner food. The waffles and pancakes are decent, but pretty much the best in the area. Their omelets are amazing. Good service.
author: Will D.

description: It's my first morning of a one week stay in Noe Valley. I spotted Toast Eatery on my morning walk down 24th St. It's got a breakfast diner feel with about a dozen locals eating when I arrived at 7:45am. I was quickly seated and served coffee. The coffee is a little bold with good body and finish. I ordered the Godfather Omelet which consists of italian sausage, red and green sweet pepper, onion, mushrooms and american cheese. It was served with a half plate of hash browns and 2 large slices of toast. the hash browns were properly cooked with a nice crust on the outside and warm in the middle. The omelet was full of flavor! The peppers, onions and mushrooms were sauted to the right texture for an omelet. I would. order it again. The server kept my coffee filled and delivered the check before I finished (I appreciate that). The meal came to $15.44 without tip (coffee was $2.95). It was a lot of food and I didn't finish the toast. I do not understand some of the mediocre reviews. My experiance was enjoyable while tasty and filling. I will be back and recomend Toast Eatery to others.
author: Lenny S.

description: Great eggs benedicts.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Been here a couple times. I've ordered eggs benedict and florentine here before and wasn't super impressed, but not disappoint either. I really don't like their hash browns though. There isn't enough to sop the sauces and yolks and the square shape bothers me. Other people I've been with have been disappointed with proportion sizes but were generally happy with their meals (such as the French dip sandwich). If you arrive at the right time on certain days, the bowl of fresh fruit is truly amazing and the freshest I've had in any restaurant.

Last time I went was for my 21st birthday with a friend. But on my birthday, my friend and I had the waffle with strawberries and it was the best waffle I've had in a while. 

Beverage wise, I usually stick with orange juice, but I got a mimosa which was to my liking. The ratio of alcohol to orange juice was perfect. I'm tiny for the most part and not a constant drinker so if I get something strong, I usually have to make sure I eat a lot to sop it up. This was not the case though, which is why they get a 4.
author: Joanna A.

description:
I had the veggie omelette--fresh, crisp veggies galore!  
Portions = hearty
Prices = good
Greaseless diner food rules!
Service = friendly and attentive.
Decor = shade of toast. Trust me.  But I do like the artwork on the walls!

I'll have to come back to try their sammiches!
author: Fannie S.

description: If you would like a good breakfast and you're in Noe Valley, do not hesitate to order one here. I had the Church Street omelette, Avocado, Spinach, Bacon, Onions & Cheddar, and it was excellent. Coffee (beans from Mr. Espresso) was very good. My wife had the hash benedict, and that was great also. The portion was just right, not too HUGE, and definitely enough. Pleasant wait staff. Lot of people like the hash browns, including my wife, they were not my favorite - crispy on the outside, kind of mushy except for the browned cripy part. I paid the extra 1.75 for fruit instead of hash browns, and the fruit was good.
author: James P.

description:
Skip the pancakes.  Skip the bacon.

I was truly disappointed with this morning's Toast Eatery experience.  My husband and I shared a full order of buckwheat banana pancakes with a side order of bacon.  The pancakes came out cold and very dry.  The bananas were on top, not cooked into the pancakes (but I should've asked about this).  The bacon was AWFUL!  It tasted like it had been doused in flour, then ironed.  Yuck.  

I would not eat here again if I hadn't had three better experiences.

Stick with eggs, hash browns, and toast.  I've had several yummy breakfasts at Toast following these guidelines.  I've also enjoyed a delicious pear salad for dinner.

Lesson learned.
author: Kristin M.

description:
I want to give this place a 3.5, but since Yelp doesn't allow for half stars I am giving them a bump up for doing one of my favorite sandwiches well :)

I met a friend here for lunch on a Friday afternoon. The wait wasn't too long and the atmosphere was light and casual.

I ordered the reuben which was made with  a great quality corn beef, swiss, ranch on rye.  Quite tasty! What got me was the meat quality. I'm happy to say that it wasn't fatty and was still very flavorful.  I got hash browns instead of the fries and was very happy with my decision.

The service was good and the price was right.

They serve breakfast all day so next time I am going to dig in to some pancakes :)

Simple food done well at a good price.  What more could you ask for?
author: DJ N.

description: Last time I went here there was a line out the door, but they did a great job of seating people fast. And no doubt the food is very good.
author: Oliver B.

description:
I wanted to treat my friend that helped me on a photoshoot. I told her to pick a brunch place and though I don't like waiting, it's a sign that people in the neighborhood likes it.

Nice breakfast and most of all a great compliment to the wonderful strong coffee. Extra star for  the coffee!

Great waitress too.
author: Brandon M.

description:
Menu items are way over-priced.  A fountain drink was $2.50 and a BLT was $9.75!

The bacon was more fat than meat and the tomatos were pale.

This restaurant re-uses Heinz bottles with lesser-grade ketchup.  How weak is that?
author: Hank S.

description:
The service was terrible but I don't believe that 1 star is warranted based on a bad experience, with a miserable restaurant manager with poor customer service skills, alone. 

But 1 star is absolutely warranted if the food is awful, poor quality AND overpriced!!! I ordered the breakfast combo of eggs, hashbrowns, ham and pancakes. It was the Denny's Grand Slam - except it cost $10.95!!! My brother ordered a scramble, literally came with two slices of american cheese melted on top - super classy! The entire table was extremely disappointed in the food - extremely!

We did have an awful experience with a woman whom we assumed was the manager, though given that she acted so incredibly rude, it now seems doubtful. I don't need to go into that, but did want to take the public opportunity to let her know that the entire table thought she was a ..... less than pleasant person.

We left the place feeling rather regretful that we strayed away from our usual favorite restaurant - Savor, right down the street. Better food, better service, better atmosphere - same price. Delicious savory and sweet crepes, breakfast all day,  seasoned home-fries (not some disgusting, greasy, Denny's style hash-browns), the same staff has been happily working there for years, yummy burgers and sandwiches, incredible salads and pretty much every dish comes with an amazing side salad, creme brulee is a secret item not found on the menu - order it, awesome back patio with heaters and an awning, the cooks are jolly happy guys that do good work. Go there instead and leave a much happier yelp reviewer!
author: Michele C.

description:
I loved Toast and will certainly eat there again. For their delicious food I wrote a haiku of praise. 

Adorable Toast
San Francisco's tiny treat
You make breakfast good
author: Lee P.

description: I wouldn't judge them quite so harshly if their prices weren't so gouge-y. You walk in, and no one greets you for quite a while. The food is okay (but may be getting cold by the time it arrives at your table), nothing special, AND you'll pay big for it. That was Toast's last chance and I won't be back.
author: Kathy R.

description:
i love the place not as much as i should do.
the service again, you better be "lucky".
the bosser works harder than the waitress
author: B H.

description: Awesome place!! Great atmosphere and d'lish food!! Service was good and I really enjoyed myself!!!
author: Mateo J.

description: So I walked in wanting something on the healthy side to eat.  I passed by and saw a dude eating a very delicate salad. So I'm in.... The place looks like a french bistro/retro diner. I sit at the bar area.  Ordered a hummus sandwich with avocado  and a salad.  The hummus had way too much tahini in it.  So much, in fact the nuttiness tasted almost like some food that was scorched in a pot. The funny part about it was that the amount of hummus was barely there.  Like you would dress the sand which with very little mayo. If there was anymore hummus on the sandwich I probably would have gagged.  Their greens were tasty though I guess overall it hit the spot for what I wanted at the moment.  Service is ok. I'll give it another try. BTW bring your own salt.
author: A K.

description: My go-to place for comfort food and all-day breakfast! Lines could be long especially in the morning, and orders could take a while especially when packed, but don't hesitate to remind them about your order.
author: Thea T.

description: Food is not bad. American diner cuisine. If you're looking for a quick meal without any expectations of exceptional quality, this is the place for you. It's in a charming area in Noe Valley. Lots of people watching. I find the service to be very nice. Parking may be difficult on weekend morning. But I'd definitely say try it out.
author: James M.

description:
The food we had was very average.  The veggie burger was too dry to eat without applying heaps of condiments. 

And DO not come if you want a kid free environment.  We ate there on Friday night (7pm) and the place was packed with kids (50% plus).  

The only plus was the efficient service.
author: Aus B.

description:
I have been living in SF for about seven months now.  I have visited Stacks, Just For You, Farmer Browns, and a few other breakfast places.  All great.... But TOAST has me writing a review.  I was going to give it a solid 4 stars, but after reading what others had to say I had to give them an extra star because I think some of the bad reviews are way off the mark. 

I had the French Toast and it was GREAT! My wife had a Waffle and her cousin a scramble.  It was all good stuff! 

I also liked the service, and the people that were eating in the joint.  They also had a GIANTS flag up and nice art! 

d
author: Dominic A.

description: Great French fries. Decent Mac n cheese for kids.
author: olivia b.

description:
WOW!
You know what Yelp? You're a better adviser than a crowd. Unfortunately I learned this the hard way.  I didn't check the reviews for Toast, but decided to brunch there because there is ALWAYS a line out front, usually a surefire indicator of a tasty treat.

I guess the Noe isn't tuned into the Yelp.

It was warm and pleasant, with Sirron Norris illustrations on the walls.  Menu looked good, coffee was probably the best cafe coffee ever.  Rich, dark, earthy.  The waitress was super nice.  It seemed like things were going well.

But then the food, oh dear lord, the food. The presentation was terrible. Eggs, toast, and undercooked hash browns just plopped on a too-big plate. It was a decent meal that appeared tiny and unceremoniously prepared.  The food was alright, but nothing I'd ever rave about. Why, Toast? You look like the kind of breakfast spot that knows how to make a stellar meal, but you just didn't deliver.  

Someone should go undercover to St. Francis to see how it's done. I volunteer!
author: Mari C.

description: For a place with a waiting list and people lined out the door I thought it would be better. The menu was standard fair and not many options for lunch. I got the Eggs Benedict with what I thought was bacon but was more a mixed round slice of processed ham and hash browns. The servers must've been really busy b/c a refill was hard to come by.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Pretty good breakfast spot. I have been pleased every time I have been. Though, I usually stick with lunch choices.The burger on a sourdough baguette is my favorite!
author: Ryan H.

description:
Pretty good food.  Great ham scramble and corn beef hash.  But the corn beef has did NOT sit well in my stomach.  Probably too greasy.

If you're a lonely, horny guy, grab a seat at the counter.  There's one waitress who would constantly brush her boobs along the counter while taking your order.  I mean to the point my husband openly asked me "Is she trying to show me her boobs?"  I recommend every single, straight guy to have breakfast there.  She works on Saturdays :)
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
I FIRST WANT TO GIVE A BIG SHOUT OUT TO MY TOAST EATERY GIRLS:  

CHELSEA
JESSICA
TRACI

They made me feel so welcome tonight.  I hate dining alone but I felt like I didn't because these girls made me feel like I had company.   And best of all they didn't even make a bad comment when I went healthy with my AMAZINGLY GENEROUS chef salad but I ruined my healthy attempt with the most delicious item to come out of that kitchen - HASH BROWNS (read my Yelp review of Toast Eatery on Church).  I have already warned them I am coming in drunk one night and ordering the plate of hash browns with the sour cream and black olives and all the other good stuff!  

I have been anticipating the opening of this place for close to a year.  I spilled the beans about it to my favorite blog sf.eater.com I have been peaking in the window wondering about the progress.  Well folks if you were die hard Herb's (may they rest in peace) please don't take your Herb's attitude to Toast.  It is a different place.  BUT THEY DID GIVE A NICE TRIBUTE TO HERB'S.  Just look at the big piece of toast hanging above the restroom.  You will understand when you go in and check it out.  

I tell you don't wait, RUN, get in there, because this weekend is opening weekend and it will be crazy.  Those Noe Valley people who don't travel beyond the confines of 24th Street will kick themselves that they never made way down to Church and Day.  

I was excited to learn they are open until 10:00.  Not sure if that is all nights but tonight they most certainly are open until then. I say if Pomodoro can do it so can Toast.  

I just hope on Saturday and Sunday mornings they don't kick me out for bringing in my BERNIE'S COFFEE from across the street.  I love a good Bernie's and so does the rest of the hood.  My prediction is in due time it will be on the menu as well. 

Seriously this was my first dinner experience at my favorite breakfast spot.  I will be going back over and over again.  (Shhh inside scoop...maybe they will be putting some dinner items on the menu as time goes on!)   You didn't hear that from me.

My mornings will be forever changed when I walk out the door of my apartment building and smell the yumminess of the place we call Toast Eatery.

Chelsea, Jessica, and Traci hang in there girls you are going to get lots of business but remember...I gave you the first shout out! 

Thanks from the guy who lives across the street!
author: Scott P.

description: so so food for a lot of bucks.  I ordered the Toast Scramble with tofu instead of eggs and was it real boring.  Even the mocha I ordered was sleepy.  I was with a large party and there were some who were happy with their meal.  Just an average place with average food.  I agree with the Denny's reference from an earlier review.
author: Chris B.

description:
I live nearby but only came here after over a year. The lines outside on the weekends scream "hipster joint", but when I set foot inside on a weeknight for some dinner take-out, the ambiance was more locals' family-friendly establishment.

Chicken cheese steak and corned beef hash are both appropriately greasy and tastily spot-hitting.
author: Rob T.

description: As someone who lives in this neighborhood, this is definately one of the best places to grab breakfast/brunch in this area
author: Nate W.

description:
Yuppy Denny's.  Buckwheat Pancakes had a strange after taste.  Hash browns were frozen.  

Prices were not too high... service was good.... thanks for the NO stroller rule

other then that...  this place is so-so
author: Christopher F.

description: I am constantly impressed with the service whenever I come here. The food is always amazing, and the prices are extremely fair for the amount of food you get. I always tip generously to the servers who are there in the mid afternoon, and they are extremely nice! Thanks Toast for giving me my crack. Breakfast food!
author: Keenan M.

description:
I love that this place is called an "eatery" versus "restaurant." I love that it has toast-inspired art on the walls. I love that it has big windows and sits in the heart of Noe. I did not, however, love my brunch.

Based on recommendation, we took our out-of-town visitors to Toast for brunch on Saturday. There was about a 20 minute wait which wasn't a big deal. The five of us were seated and handed menus. I noticed that the prices were about $2 more than my favorite brunch spot, Lower Haight's The Grind. They even had my lox scramble, but for $11.95 I decided against it.

Three of us ordered eggs and two ordered salad. My turkey scramble tasted fine, but the presentation was a D+ at best. The eggs had a square of cheese poorly melted on top, and the hashbrowns were also a crispy square, cut from a mold. It was also a pretty small portion, although I support their efforts at portion control. My friend ordered the salmon salad, and having asked for no bleu cheese, got a bed of greens with a formerly-frozen looking chunk of salmon and a few cherry tomatoes. Another friend commented that her salad was bland. I can't say that I need to go back. Next time, I'll check out a Noe bakery for brunch.
author: Emilia S.

description:
So, I have passed this place on the 48 bus many times and always see lots of people eating here for lunch. Today I stopped for lunch and ordered some classic Eggs Benedict. I believe that if you serve eggs benedict you know how to make it well, considering that there are 4 main ingredients: Eggs, toaster muffin, Canadian bacon, and Hollandaise sauce (which is mainly butter and lemon juice). The egg was cooked correctly and the muffin was toasted right! Yay! The bacon was too chewy and I could barely cut it. The Hollandaise sauce was horrible! Where the heck was the paprika?! It was just bland and boring. Plus, the hash browns were nothing special and sat on the plate in the shape of a square. Shouldn't it be piled high in a beautiful mound of crispy potatoes? I think so.

So the food was blah. I ate half of my food, which totaled to $12.03. However, this was only half of the bad experience I had here. The "chef" at the grilled was creepily staring at me the entire time I was there! It was so awkward and made my dining experience just that much worse.

My suggestion is to stay on the 48 and pass this place by...
author: Briza Y.

description:
My review here is for the new Toast on Polk & Sacramento. I'm assuming it's the same owners/food/management rules.  

I ate there for the first time ever.  The food was so-so; I had a cheese and mushroom omelet.  The mushrooms tasted canned and the hash browns were one of those pre-frozen blocks. The price was too high generally but specifically because they add a 4% charge for "San Francisco Health Ordinance".  The prices in my opinion were high enough to cover them paying for their employees health benefit.  This is only charged to those businesses that don't (provide health insurance). It's up to the employer to pay NOT the customer.  

I don't think they will change this surcharge. I don't think I'll eat there (or at any of them) again.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Noe Valley NEEDS more breakfast joints! 

I thought it was hilarious that there is a Toast on 24th AND one on Church Street, both competing with Chloe's and Starbucks... yet there was still a line out the door at one o'clock in the afternoon on a Sunday! Annoying! 

Waited 30 minutes out in the rain with my 8 months pregnant sister for some dang eggs and hash browns...

Totally worth it!

Once we FINALLY got seated the food came fast and hot, the coffee was strong, the omelet was AWESOME and the service was efficient (maybe not friendly but as long as I get a smile and the coffee/water/food comes quickly I don't really care all that much!).

Only reason I knocked a star off was watching the bus-person clean off the tables was maddening. Like molasses! AND got 'tude from one waitress when I asked her if they were going to start seating people in the two empty tables I saw sitting in the window for 20 minutes! Turns out they were waiting to seat a large party. If she'd told me that nicer maybe I'd give five stars???

And! I think they need to open a third and fourth location in Noe! 

We like breakfasts and brunches in San Francisco!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
I find it funny how people that are not from a particular neighborhood will talk shit about going into another neighborhood. If babies and dogs offend you. Keep your ass in your own neighborhood and stop being a whiny bitch. 
The menu isn't creative. It's a tad expensive, but I know what the rents go for on this street and all the lovely taxes that business owners pay. 
Toast beats the hell outa Denny's or whatever shit hole you can eat at for less. Pick your poison. This place is a diner. What do you expect? 
The chefs salad is awesome. The Reuben sandwich is great and so is the hot pastrami. Get the sweet potato fries. The regular ones get cold easy and taste like a rubber band. 
The service is decent enough. I'm not asking for a happy ended with my sandwich. I'm the kinda guy that wants my food and be left alone.
author: Deejay K.

description:
I have been visiting SF on the weekends now for a couple weeks and drinking heavily. After waking up groggy on a Saturday morning i love coming here to chase away the hunger pangs. Good ole fashioned American style breakfast like mom used to make. Its so good in fact it almost makes me want to move back to the Midwest. Almost.

I think i am starting to wear on the servers patience but sometimes i like playing the part of an annoying hungover gay guy. Or maybe she thinks im being cute... who knows. 

Any they have espresso vanilla milkshakes! you owe it to yourself to enjoy one with each meal. I do!
author: Jeff H.

description:
While visiting San Francisco on vacation we stayed in Noe Valley.
Toast was our last breakfast stop before heading to the airport on our way out of town.
We had heard it was great, but we were disappointed.
The food was Ok, not spectacular, and the prices were higher than expected.  That coupled with the unimpressive wait staff and the experience was not memorable.
This was a bit of a letdown given the other excellent restaurants we had experienced up and down 24th while in town.
We'll look for an alternative for breakfasts when we're in town again.
author: Mark B.

description:
Really noisy. A lot of small children (and parents who make no attempt to quiet them). Bad acoustics add to the mix. 

Food is average at best (mosty cold when it finally gets to you).

Waitress with an "attitude" but with reason: only one waitress for the whole restaurant.

Place to go if you're living in Noe Valley and don't care about ambiance, quality or service.

Wouldn't go back. Much better places all around.
author: Thomas B.

description: Toast is fast becoming my favorite brunch place. It is within walking distance to my house, not too hard to get a seat on weekend if you go early (10ish), and it has all my food needs: aromatic smooth coffee, solid good wheat/rye toast, fruit substitutions, and scrambles that can be made with tofu. I have recently found that egg scrambles are a bit too much for my stomach in the early mornings, so have started trying tofu scrambles everywhere, and somehow this is the place that just seems to get the combination of flavors right. I've tried the veggie and joe scrambles w tofu and both are excellent! And someday...I'll indulge myself in their fruit stacked pancakes!
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Came here with some ladies for some brunch.  I got the Noe Valley scramble and it was quite good for a good price!

The service was nice and it  was a cute place!
author: Nancy C.

description:
The food is pretty good and a nice portion for those of us who can't get enough food when it comes to brunch. =) 

The omelette's are pretty tasty and a decent size as are most of their dishes.  Pancakes... well... are just pancakes...  
I usually do the create your own  omlette..egg white.,. spinach.. mushroom and cheese.. sometimes it comes out a bit greasy but that has been on a very rare occasion. 

It's usually pretty crowded and sometimes can be a bit overwhelming when you have a bunch of people waiting outside. It's also pretty small so if you are claustrophobic you would have a better time at a place that has more space.  ( not as small as the one on church street though) 

Overall a cool place to go for breakfast/lunch.
Make sure you give yourself ample time to find parking though. Sometimes it can be kind of a pain.
author: Lisette E.

description:
It started at about 5 pm on Saturday, a fifth of the way through a bar crawl that wound up with me tossing around an inflatable killer whale balloon in the back of a taxi cab. I got it in my head and I wasn't going back.

I hungered for it. I desired it. I told all my friends and they were horrified that I would discuss such a thing at a bar crawl. I told my boyfriend and he shrugged it off as the passing whim of a drunk girl.

When I woke up Sunday, the craving was still there. And this time, the boy wanted it too.

Oh yes. A chocolate milkshake would be mine.

Toast's milkshake, in particular, was able to alleviate the sugar pangs of hangover hell. Extra thick and made with what seemed like dark chocolate ice cream and topped with a pile of fluffy whipped cream, it was perfect. 

The whole menu seemed diner-ific and therefore ideal for what we needed. We both had the house-made corned beef hash, which was nice and hearty. The combination of the salty hash and the sweet shake served our headaches and rumbling bellies well. The 30-45 minute wait was long forgotten when we sat and ate in gluttonous silence.

My only complaint really comes from the amount of people stuffed in the restaurant. We were elbow to elbow with the neighboring tables and actually wound up exchanging pleasantries with both, but had I felt better perhaps I could have mustered more than a few well-intentioned grunts. 

Oh, but that milkshake. It was worth it.
author: Devon S.

description:
Contrary to what some people believe, just because you take bread dough and bake it into a torus shape doesn't mean it's a bagel.  Call it lox and round bread, at least it won't be false advertising!

Anyway, I appreciate the fact that you can get breakfast for dinner here up until around 9pm. That's such a rare thing to find in the area, heck breakfast for a 5pm dinner is hard enough! The food is generally pretty decent, and the menu is fairly vast with many breakfast and lunch type choices (from oatmeal to hamburgers) and the service is around what you would expect for a diner in Noe (a cut above standard diner service). 

I'll go back, but the bagel thing just rubs me the wrong way!
author: neil c.

description:
A solid breakfast place that is hurt by their own popularity.

The problem with Toast is the wait.  If it's sunny out and everyone's outside and you'd like to get breakfast at decent hour you'll wait for more than 30 minutes.  This is a due both of the facts that the place is small and very popular.

On the other hand there are good things-

Food.  Good variety of breakfast item with consistently solid quality.  The hash brown is always crispy, the fruit always fresh.  I like their ground turkey omelette a lot (I think it's called "Mission").

Price.  Decent price of about $12 per person which is a fair amount for what you get.

Location.  Right in the heart of Noe Valley shopping area and there's a lot to do in and around the hood. On a sunny day it's a good way to start the day to have breakfast here and then walk around the neighborhood known as 'stroller and doggie country'.
author: Andi H.

description: Cute little diner. I got the Corned Beef Eggs Benedict.  Coffee was filled promptly refilled. Service was very good. But nothing really wowed me about this place. It's a nice, convenient place for breakfast in Noe Valley, but I'd rather spend a little more money and go somewhere a little nicer.
author: Katie L.

description:
Meh.

The Good: Open before 10 AM midweek in Noe Valley, diverse menu, efficient service.  

The Bad: Boring food, over-mediated diner decor as predictable as the food.  

The Ugly: N/A

Points for speed. Was in and out in about 30 minutes. But had no desire to linger anyway. My sourdough French toast was fine. Other dishes on the table looked equally filling but unexciting.
author: Mikol G.

description: I was hoping for better but there are many places out there better than this place.  Long wait outside but I do give them credit for their good strong coffee
author: Pedro U.

description: I hate how small this place is, not the best place to go for groups but i will say it makes up for it with the food.
author: Paulina C.

description:
Noe, you give me so much that is good in the world - sunshine, parades of dogs, battalions of baby strollers, coffee, and peace and quiet.

But even in my podunk hometown, Toast would fare about average, and average is me being kindly.

Your food is like a blockbuster movie I laugh through because everyone else is laughing and I feel weirder not laughing than faking it.  The relative who slaves away cooking a Thanksgiving feast when at the end of the day, the turkey just tastes like turkey, the green beans, like plain old green beans.  The friend who extols the virtues of Thomas Kinkade.  The baby that attracts hormonal females when you secretly find him "weird looking."  [In fact, if your food were weird, I might like it even more.  Don't ask, I can't explain.] 

I may only walk a few blocks to reach your door, I may only wait a few minutes to get one of the coveted seats (stuck between the dad and kid duo and the hipster couple with the loud yapping girl who's clearly annoying her boyfriend), I may continue to shadow your doors when the boyfriend is in town . . . 

But even that is not enough.

I applaud you on being able to keep your food at perfect equipoise between disappointing and memorable. I almost like you, I do, but it takes a lot for me to get excited about eggs and carbs.  

Your toast? Toasty.
Your omelets? The eggs are cooked, and yep, there's stuff in them.
Your hash browns? Crispy, brown.
Your orange juice? Thick, sweet sludge.

[yawn]

I'll see you again, Toast.  I'll even write my name three lines down on your sign up sheet.  I won't be able to help myself.  I'll succumb to the hype.  Just don't expect me to cheer.
author: Sarah W.

description:
I finally had breakfast at the nicely designed Toast today, but was disappointed. The conditions were ideal: No line, no impatient kids, plenty of empty tables. We ordered classic breakfasts: 2 over easy, bacon, hashbrowns, coffee. The server was fast and attentive. I was surprised that the food arrived so quickly. Well, maybe too quickly! The eggs were fine, but the bacon was nearly cold and completely flattened, as were the greasy potatos. No way were they cooked to order!  Even the toast was cold! I suspect they were anticipating a big crowd, so maybe the bacon and flattened hashbrowns were prepared ahead of time, then sat around for awhile, under a press. There should be a disclaimer on the door: "In busy times, we batch-cook the meals, in order to serve you quickly".  I had much better breakfasts when Herb's held that spot, and likely won't be back. 
Larry
author: laurence c.

description: Good standard breakfast but no notable menu items.
author: Alison F.

description: I`ve been eating at Toast for a while now. Haven`t eaten nothing I didn`t like. The staff and cooks are super nice. I highly recommend Toast!
author: Andrew T.

description:
Solid 3 Stars. This is a practical breakfast/brunch/lunch place. Come here if you just want one. The food was good...but not amazing. The service was...alright.

My friend ordered the Mediterranean scramble - delicious. The hash browns were super crispy...I like it when they're more soft inside but crispy on the outside.

I ordered the Chef Salad with poppy seed dressing. There wasn't that much dressing, or it was just extremely light, to the point where there was hardly enough flavor. Had to order blue cheese dressing on the side! It was really just alright...had hardboiled eggs, avocado, cheese, ham, turkey, sprouts (which I liked), lettuce, tomato, olives...and with a baguette. It was just okay.

It was just okay but everything else on the menu looked good. Like the macadamia/coconut pancakes! Next time maybe.

The service...well they just seemed like they wanted NOTHING to do with that place. Yes they filled my water, but they weren't that friendly and frankly just brought nothing to my table (metaphorically speaking of course!).
author: Eryn K.

description: The food is just ok. Not bad, but not great either. The individual who seemed to be the manager was rude. We tried it because of its convenient location. There are plenty of good places nearby for breakfast with better food and nicer staff.
author: A C.

description: we were taking a dog walk in the city and got hungry so we wandered down to this place because we thought it looked good. it was very busy when we got there and the smell coming from the kitchen was TO DIE FOR, so we asked for a seat outside and no problem we were seated right away, even though they were packed. i ordered the french toast and my dad ordered eggs and my other dad ordered a breakfast burrito. when the food came out i loved the way they decorated the plates. i tried one bite of my french toast and i will never forget it. their french toast was the best i have ever had and believe me i have had lots!!! i recommend this spot as having great breakfast and i will definitely be going back again sometime soon.
author: Ford W.

description:
I grew up right around the corner and loved Herb's Fine Foods for what it was. . .divey diner with solid, greasy, home cooked food at a good price with friendly servers who had worked there for years.

I'm moving back to the old 'hood, so I couldn't wait to try Toast.  I have to say I was disappointed and I'll probably be going further afield in my quest for breakfast in the City.

First of all, there was utter confusion about the wait list, so who needs that stress.  
Second, I was a solo diner so I had to wait longer for a counter seat.  This is okay, I hate to take up a two-top, but it was still a little frustrating.
Third, I was IGNORED for over 10 minutes.  I understand it's busy, but a nod, or a "Ill be right with you" or a person who only gets water and coffee as soon as someone is seated would be a nice touch.
Fourth, I ordered the coconut/banana pancakes, and there was hardly any coconut.  I did not realize I had to order syrup separately and I was not offered any, and it was too busy for me to request any.
Fifth, I ordered sausage and the order consisted of 1 and 1/2 links.  That's just weird!

Not worth the wait or the cost as far as I'm concerned.
author: Anna B.

description:
I'd give it 4 stars for my breakfast *if* it wasn't an establishment that specializes in breakfast! The breakfast was good but not great. My omelette was the best part of my meal.

The hash browns looked and tasted as though I could have gotten them at a fast food establishment. No flair at all. And honestly, there was nothing special about the toast we received that day, which is weird since the place is named Toast Eatery. Furthermore, there was no strawberry jam on the table, and after asking for some, a single packet was brought to our table.

It was an OK meal, but I don't understand why it was packed. Perhaps if you live in the neighborhood, it may be the best choice (don't know, don't live there). If you're visiting SF and don't mind braving the Tenderloin, then check out the amazing Dottie's True Blue Cafe!
author: Ryan S.

description: I wish the service was ad good as the food. Again this place over all is average at best. I wish the server paid attention to the guests as much as she did counting her tips. She won't have to worry about counting my tip...pretty hard to count nothing.
author: Larry M.

description: mmmMMM how I love hash browns. Especially ones that are crunchy and still have the soft potato bite inside. This place do them good!!! Go with a friend, so one can get savory and the other can get a sweet one. We shared a savory platter and got the belgium waffles with strawberries on them. The waffles were great. Crunchy on the outside and soft in the inside. Just how I like them and sweet with my strawberries.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I love breakfast.  Probably got it from my mom who used to take me out for breakfast a lot as a kid.  This was in Florida before the days of fancy omelettes and organic ANYTHING.  You had a choice of hashbrowns or grits and coffee was just that hot brown liquid that came out of the pot.  You want milk in your coffee?  Just help yourself to those little plastic tubs of half and half on the table there.   (Someone please tell me why those things don't have to be refrigerated.)

So, I tend to be generous with any establishment that serves breakfast. I'm just happy they exist.  I have always been satisfied with my experiences at Toast.  The service is fine - one waitress in particular is very friendly.  The food is simple and fresh and yummy.  

I think in San Francisco we tend to have heightened expecations of our restaurants.  We forget that we live in an absolute food Mecca.  Excuse me, but the San Francisco version of "satisfactory" is well above average in most parts of the country.  We are so freakin' spoiled.  I just have to remember the days in college - getting a blank look when I asked for tofu in a CHINESE restaurant.  Here in SF it's practically de rigueur for breakfast places to have a tofu scramble, and Toast, of course, delivers.  It warms my heart.
author: Molly T.

description:
We had breakfast here this morning. Have walked by a million times with a super long line. There was no line this morning and a two-top table open in the front. So we went and had our breakfast at Toast finally. Well, I can see why they have a 3-star average. Not that great, a little overpriced. 

For example, I got the waffles w/the blueberries, strawberries, bananas & nutella (sounds great right?) but unfortunately would cost an extra $2 for real maple syrup. What? I can see why people joke about smuggling in their own maple syrup because of places like this. I mean c'mon, I paid nearly $8 for the waffles and you can't give me a lil drop of syrup? I mean, $1 I might have gone for but $2? I am not heavy handed w/my syrup... Also, the waffles were rich yet had a rubbery consistency. Wah. 

My breakfast date got the corned beef hash and eggs. Eggs were overcooked, hash was okay but definetly for both meals "meh, I've experienced better" is right. We could have made a better breakfast at home and would have but decided we'd give toast a chance, well we gave it one, and we won't be returning. 

Your money is way better spent at a place like Kate's Kitchen where you pay less, get more, have better quality, service and ambiance. Did enjoy the people/dog watching from the window though. ;)

Why anyone in their right mind would ever wait to eat here let alone return here is beyond me... Go elsewhere or take advantage of the Noe Valley Farmer's Markets (Tues & Sun) and make your own meal.
author: Abby W.

description:
I LOVE NUTELLA...so this place was great!
The breakfast food was delicious!
author: Ivy G.

description:
A solid reliable breakfast restaurant that is conveniently placed.

I enjoyed Toast and they are pretty traditional but I've had better in the past. I had their 24th Street Omelette which was tasty, and my friend had the Egg's Florentine. 

Both were good but if you compare to a place like Mission Beach Cafe, MBC hands down is better, but is definitely pricier
author: Eric A.

description: walk in for lunch. near empty but not a problema as I slid into the counter. Very cute waitress gets me my drink fast, and I order what was a so so under toasted not melted grilled cheese with fries that were soggy and also undercooked... fast service...maybe a tad too fast...I could of waited the extra few minutes for some color on my fries and some melt on my cheese..but this is a nice place and I am sure they do better!
author: Ricote F.

description:
Pretty good, typical all American breakfast: bacon, scrambled eggs, french toast in a cozy little restaurant.  

Great location, nice atmosphere, great service not bad for a casual friendly eatery joint.
author: Stacy L.

description:
For the price, I think the food here is quite average. The scrambles were a bit dry, and the hashed browns seem like the frozen reheated kind (which may be a big positive for some). If you like bacon cooked on the dry side, you will be satisfied. The pancakes are average, but the waffles are good.

The service is quite good, and it gets the Noe Valley stamp of approval for child friendliness. The counter is spacious if you choose to eat there, and there is almost room to read the paper.

It's good enough for a weekday morning when there is no line, you're hungry, and you want convenience. But it always puzzles me when I see long lines on the weekend. I admit I do go back once every few months after working overnight, but I always feel somewhat dissatisfied after leaving each time.
author: Greg N.

description:
Came here this past Sunday before leaving SF to come back to L.A.  I've been to the other location and LOVED it.  Toast has been the only restaurant successful at making me eat my hash browns.  

Anyways, I came to this location and was so glad we got seated immediately.  I ordered their Corned Beef Hash with scrambled eggs, an english muffin, hash browns (of course!), and an orange juice.  I was so impressed with the size of their OJ.  A lot of places try to rip you off and give you a small little cup of juice for $3-$5.  Hell to the no!  I need my OJ for my AMs so needless to say, Toast was off to a great start.

When my Corned Beef Hash came, I was so relieved it looked NOTHING like the Corned Beef Hash served at Craig's Place.  Toast knew how to do it right with the hash (note to Craig's: that's potatoes for you) and small strips of beef.  **Drool**  AND here's why I love their hash browns:  it's crispy on the outside all around but soft and potatoe-y on the inside!  Perfect texture!

My friend and I also ordered a side of Chicken Apple Sausage to share and I have to say, still good.  You can really taste the apples that give it a special sweetness.  Unlike Craig's.  (It's funny because Craig's Place has almost the same exact menu as Toast)

My friend ordered their Eggs Benedict which I had to try.  And just like everything else, it was very good.  

I've yet to experience bad service at Toast but I must warn you, do be prepared to wait.  They usually have very long lines (at least at the Church location) that may cause you to wait 15+ minutes.  I think it's worth it.  YOU should try it out to see if it's worth it.

On the financial side (let's face it, we're all broke!), it might be considered on the pricier range.  For two OJs, an Eggs Benedict, Corned Beef Hash, and a side of Chicken Apple Sausage, our bill came out to $35.03, not including tip.  For me, it's totally worth it.
author: Linh V.

description:
Pretty good, didn't knock my socks off. Eggs florentine was good - I think the yolk was slightly cooked, and the hollandaise sauce was decent. Not gross, but not delicious either. The omelette was pretty good though. oh, the hash browns - ask for them crispy, because the crispy parts were YUM. 

I noticed that the baked goods weren't fresh. just FYI. Maybe it was just that day? I'd go here if it were the only brunch place in town. But its not! There are so many to try..
author: Carol L.

description: I feel like I can get everything here for two dollars less and that tastes 20% better at various other places.  Hipster diner.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
We happened upon this place when we passed up Pasta P because of the kid sitch.  Like too many of them.  SO, we got a seat up at the bar which was totally fine but again, the place was pretty kid filled.  I'm probably going to offend the parent's out there but you should be offended if you actually make your kids behave in a public place.  So yeah, could have done without the kids screaming, crawling under the tables and running around but I digress.  

I had a bitchin French Dip sando which was awesome.  Good roast beef, no fat and a great sourdough french bread.  The Au Jus was very tasty as well.  I got a salad with their homemade poppyseed dressing which was good but next time I'll go fries.  I would definitely go back...maybe just a little bit later =)
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Certainly some of the worst breakfast food in the city.

Ate at Toast for the first and last time this morning. We had two items: a blueberry waffle and the hashbrown and cheese pile; both breakfast-spot standards, and I would say pretty hard to screw up.

When my wife's waffle arrived she commented after testing with a fork that it appeared to be a frozen waffle. I laughed - "why would they sell a frozen waffle - it wouldn't even save them much money," I said. Then I tried a bite. Almost certainly a frozen waffle, unless it was left over from the day before. Rubbery, flavorless, in short awful. The blueberries were..edible. The "real maple syrup" we paid 2 bucks extra for was almost certainly watered down with fake maple syrup. 

I fared no better with my plate of hash browns, cheese, sour cream and olives. This is a plate you order for bulk, since potatoes are cheap. No bulk here: a flat pile of mealy grated potatoes maybe half an inch high, topped with a nearly equal amount of el-cheapo cheddar cheese, a glop of sour cream and a bunch of those nasty pre-sliced black olives from a can. I ate it, but only because I was hungry and I had to be somewhere soon, and the decent breakfast spot up the street was closed. But I couldn't believe I was paying almost ten bucks for this pile of canned glop.

My wife ordered a tea, which the server insisted in delivering in a tiny baby-sized cup--no pint glass or little teapot available. Would providing a bigger quantity of hot water affect Toast's bottom line? Not really; whoever designed the place just apparently doesn't drink tea himself.

Clearly the owners think that since they have a prime spot on 24th street in Noe Valley's main strip, they can serve whatever crap they want and rake in the money, since Noe Valley has a legal cap on the number of restaurants on 24th st. And they're probably right. People have to eat after all.

But maybe if their yelp rating dives low enough business will dry up and they'll have to sell to somebody who actually cares about feeding the customer something edible. We can only hope.
author: jack b.

description:
I was surprised to see that Toast only got 3 stars.  This is my favorite of the walk-able brunch places in the neighborhood.  People rave about Chloe's, but I think Toast is better.

The gals are super friendly, and they're always reasonably efficient.  Food is consistent.  Nothing A-MAZING, but definitely good and reliable.  I might put the hash browns in the amazing category.  Always perfectly crispy, yum.  I'm also a fan of the fruit salad.  Much nicer than your usual melon medley.

There are some secret times of day when it isn't crowded.  If you go during the peak, the wait seems endless, and that can be really frustrating.  The place is not large, and does not accommodate large groups well.
author: Kathryn M.

description:
We came to San Francisco for a couple of days and stayed at the Holiday Inn on Van Ness. Walking distance from the hotel we found this place by accident. We gave it a try for breakfast, we had Eggs benedict, Polk street omelett and childs silver dollar pancakes. Everthing was really good and was made with fresh ingredients. The check was around. $ 44.00 but it included 2 coffees and milk. Lil pricey maybe, but it was worth a good breakfast meal. It was sooooooooo good that we returned the next two days we stayed in Frisco. The next few days I ordered the same thing to my suprise. Country fried steak with country gravy, eggs over medium, hash browns made to my wish well done wth onions and cheddar cheese and of course sour dough.  I thnk it runs for $10.95. You gotta try it! Its one of the best I've tried. You won't regret it. Besides the food the staff is really nice. I highlly recommend it. Definite five stars thanks Toast you made my stay in San Francisco a memorable one.  
Mando from Los angeles
author: Armando Z.

description:
There is no doubt about it - this place has attitude! 

The decor is fancy and stylish, the menu is varied and interesting, and the waitresses are all hot and.. have attitude! 

A couple of months ago, I popped my head in the door and asked to see a menu (there is none posted in the window - what's with that?) - the nice-looking gal behind the counter gave a snappy answer about how they were closing soon. I still wanted to see a menu, but I just left. 

The lines were always long, but yesterday I was resolved to stick it out and check out the buzz around this place - was the attitude warranted? I put down a name for two people and asked how long it would be - again the attitude - nice-looking gal could not tell me - it depends on how many people on the list are still here - yeah, sure, but give me some idea, It was just a bit... off! 

The wait was about twenty minutes, which is fine (it was COLD - many people had left), We took a couple of stools at the counter (my favorite!). 

Again, I am sure the gal did not mean anything by it, but... the attitude! Somehow I felt like I was back in high-school - she was one of the cute popular grrrls and I was the awkward geek that she was deigning to even speak to! But maybe that's just me...

It was not that bad, but, in the end, the food was not that good either. The hash browns were overly crispy and the English muffins in the eggs florentine were tough. 

I am a sucker for a homemade veggie burger - and they have them with mushrooms and rise. I will be back for that - it has to be worth another shot - right? Worth putting up with the attitude? Or maybe, like high school, I just want to hang out with the cute, popular girls!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
Came here for a late Sunday breakfast recently. There was a wait, but we missed most of the breakfast crowd. 

The Belgian waffle was forgettable, aside from the mounds of fresh blueberries. The omelet, in contrast, was delightful, chock full of feta, spinach, and sun-dried tomatoes. I couldn't get enough of the hash browns, either. They were crisp and filling, and just enough to share. 

Thank you so much to the server who kept my coffee filled and brought me out some more of those sun-dried tomatoes because I was still half-asleep and didn't see them at first.
author: alejandro p.

description: Toast is always busy, tidy, and pretty to look at. The food, however, is oddly bland and inoffensive. Underwhelming, in a word.
author: Michael S.

description:
I had been hearing a lot about TOAST as of late so I decided to order some breakfast for take out this morning.

I went with a breakfast burrito

PROS:

i liked the addition of avocado and sour cream into the mix,a departure from any breakfast burrito Ive ever had before .The salsa was tasty too

CONS:

I am really into hash browns/potatoes with breakfast food and I judge a breakfast spot for how they make their taters.this place does basically nothing to theirs.no seasoning ..no nothing.just shredded potatoes fried.Kinda uninteresting


I'll be back.I want to try their eggs benny next time since thats my jam usually
author: Lauren V.

description: Toast has become one of my favorite Noe Valley takeout establishments; the service is fast and reliable, and orders are consistently ready ten to fifteen minutes after I place them. The pear salad is fresh and particularly good with added grilled chicken, and the sandwiches are tasty (the chicken pesto in particular). The fries -- both the regular and the sweet potato -- are good. When I have eaten at the restaurant, service has always been fast and friendly. Oddly enough, I have never tried weekend brunch (the sidewalk is always crowded, so it must be decent!).
author: Katie M.

description:
I like the Toast on Church street much better, and it's closer to my house, but since my friend was arriving in Noe Valley via 48-Quintara, I said I'd meet her here.

I'll be honest, I've had almost everything on their menu and most of it is par, San Francisco American food. The ingredients are fresh and a lot of them are locally-sourced. And, like most "hey, we're local!" places they have omelets and sandwiches named for nearby attractions. 

So, when you're looking for a "taste of Noe Valley" go with the Noe Valley-named food like the hash brown hill (hash browns, cheese, green onions, sour cream, avocado and black olives); if you need protein ask for an egg on top.
author: Elena C.

description:
You're not Herb's. 

Your food is not good, you have all the atmosphere of a Hollister in Milpitas, and your clientele makes me want to lick batteries and chew light bulbs. 

You're not Herb's. 

Your mere existence is a cosmic tragedy. You probably hastened grumpy real estate guy's death. 

Not only are you not Herb's, you are a murderer.
author: Chris R.

description:
No no no no!

How in the hell is this place so packed every weekend?

Let's break it down, shall we?

The menu:  Tricky and overpriced.  Sure, the pancakes are *only* $7, but if you want some maple syrup on top, plan on spending an additional $2.  And the selection?  Below mediocre.

The service:  Slightly rude, very inattentive.

The space:  CRAMPED.  To get to your table, you have to hope that the people next to you are willing to get up and actually slide their table over while you pass.

Cleanliness:  Non-existent.  Our creamer for the coffee had an old piece of a soggy sugar packet in it along with some orange flecks of who-knows-what.  The table and menus were sticky.

Finally... the food:  Simply not that good.  And anyway, the things that are passable are things they order out... such as Boudin bread.
author: Christine M.

description:
We stopped here last Friday night because it was hot and neither of us wanted to cook.  He had the chef salad and I had the french dip sandwich with sweet potato fries.  Both were disappointing.  

The salad had dressing pre-tossed and then all the extra ingredients piled on top...so, no dressing on them...  

The sandwich was very bland and the dipping au jus was VERY salty (that seems to be a theme in restaurants we've gone to lately...I feel like I write that a lot!)  

And finally the sweet potato fries, usually a favorite, were limp and oily.  I LOVE the ones at Taylor's in the Ferry Building.  They are the standard I compare all other sweet potato fries to...and these simply paled in comparison.

Very, VERY mediocre food.  I can't imagine why we would go back...
author: Kelly M.

description:
BRING BACK HERB'S

In the mean time, I am avoiding this overpriced low-value joint.  Savor down the street near the corner of Sanchez is a much better brunch alternative.
author: Don O.

description:
Just got back from brunch, and first and foremost, the music they had playing was incredibly annoying - something out of nightclub, not a casual brunch place. 

One way to cover up for a complete lack of ability to make any sort of good  and flavorful food is to load everything with grease and butter, which Toast did very well.

Is it too much to ask for a soda fountain? Those of us with Diet Coke addictions appreciate free refills, much like coffee-addicts receive. My heart sank when I saw that aluminum can.

I have lived in Noe Valley for about a year, and in that time I have settled my brunch routine at Joe's 24 Street Cafe...after trying a new place today, it's case closed - Joe's is by far the winner. I'm sorry, Joe, for doubting you.
author: Mollie K.

description:
Overpriced for Denny's-caliber food. Sorry if that offends anyone, but that's what I walked away thinking.

While the hamburgers looked pretty good, I decided on an omelet. I've definitely had better at other similar establishments, and didn't have to wait for an hour. I will say they had decent hash browns, though.
author: Mike K.

description:
Went here on a Saturday and it was the place to be.  There was definitely a wait.  SO I guess that's why we decided to come here.  The food must be that good, then we shall try it.

Mimosas - $6.95 :: Average, nothing bad really...

Chef Salad w/ Ranch Dressing - $9.25 :: This looked huge and filling but I wasn't satisfied with this salad for some reason.  This seemed so appetizing  but the salad as a whole didn't amuse my tongue and stomach.

Beef Cheesesteak Sandwich w/ Curley Fries - $10.25 :: This was well portioned and this tasted so delicious!  But then again, what fried food isn't?!  

Anyways, I'd come here again to try more breakfast items than lunch items.  It's definitely worth another shot.
author: Limzer L.

description: Everything we had was great and the service was excellent as well. There was a bit of a wait to get a seat, but not bad. Also, the Arnold Palmer was above average.
author: Captain B.

description:
Seems to be my go to spot for breakfast in my neighborhood.  Perhaps it's because they always seem to find a new way to incorporate lox, capers, and cream cheese into breakfast entrees.  You can get 'em in an omelet, scrambler, or on a bagel.  Other variations include a salad and burger (albeit the salmon is processed differently in these).  Large portions regardless of what you get.  

The atmosphere is a nice mix of retro and modern, and there's plenty of light.  It's pretty hopping on the weekends, so come at off times.  A bit on the pricey side, but you'll leave full and content.
author: Michael C.

description:
I've eaten at Toast a few times.  The food is decent as is the service.  But they lost my business this afternoon as I watched the owners harass an elderly man who had setup a small table to register voters and give out buttons and signs for Obama.  

The table was clearly out of the way of their entrance and quite unobtrusive.  The owners were insisting that "if someone came out with a stroller and then someone else was walking by with stroller there would be a big congestion."  Uh, right.  On and on they complained.

If you value voting, if you value free speech and if you value neighborly courtesy, then skip Toast.  You won't miss all that much anyway.
author: Matt E.

description:
Went here for the first time yesterday and ordered a breakfast burrito (which came with hash browns) and a glass of grapefruit juice.  
It arrived like a lump on an old, scratched, ugly white cafeteria-style plate, and the hash browns were actually a flat, sqare cut-out from a large pan of hash browns - dumped haphazardly on the plate next to the lump.

I really didn't want to eat off that plate, so I wound up taking it to go.

The food itself wasn't terrible, but coupled with the gross presentation and the disinterested "i'm in school and hate my job" waitstaff, *and* the fact that a burrito and glass of juice cost $15 - I'll stay home and make my breakfast, thank you very much.

Third star for location, and the fact that it's a step up from Denny's.
author: Jessie S.

description: We definitely had a good experience here but it definitely wasn't anything special.  we got the pulled pork sandwich with curly fries and the fried chicken sandwich with onion rings.  both sandwiches were pretty good and filling and their sides weren't super greasy and real tasty.  Service was good and prices were decent.  I'd definitely come back here if it was close by, but I probably wouldn't specifically seek it out.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I was happy to see that Toast had opened up a second location given how long the wait could be to sit crammed in their Church Street location. 

So, I finally made it over to this one this morning. After a brief wait, my friend and I were seated at the counter. I loved loved loved my croissant breakfast sandwich. It was a mass of yummy, buttery goodness. It could become an addiction. And, the hash browns they came with were very crispy just as I like 'em. 

My friend and I also split a short stack of pancakes. They left a lot to be desired. They had a certain flavoring that I could not put my finger on. Nutmeg? And their consistency was odd. They were kinda mealy and no amount of butter or syrup was helping. However, they washed down well with the yummy coffee they serve. 

Although on the small side, this location is nowhere near as cramped as the one on Church. And, I actually found the counter surprisingly spacious.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Super cute diner. Came for a late lunch. No wait. People were still finishing up but lots of 2-tops to spare. Chose to sit on one of the silver counter bar stools. (I like dangling my feet from a higher position.) Loved the decor, fun vibe, and easy feel of the place.

Menu had a LOT to offer. Can see why people come for brunch with its full page of egg scrambles, omelets, pancakes, and waffles. We went for the sandwiches instead. Was torn between the Patty Melt and the BLTA (bacon, lettuce, tomato, avocado) and went for the BLTA instead. I was thinking it was healthier. 

I really liked my sandwich. Served on your choice of bread (I chose wheat), the sandwich was thick with crisp crisp bacon slices (felt like 4 or 5), lettuce, tomato and avocado. Tasted super fresh and fit the bill for a hot Noe day. Comes with a side of fries or salad. Again going for the healthier option, chose the mixed greens. Tasty!

My friend had the humongo pastrami sandwich. It didn't seem big at first but with the Boudin sourdough bread, and then the inch high pastrami, not to mention the lettuce and red onions, you really have to squeeze the tops and bottoms down to take a bite. He had skinny steak fries which were super good. Stick straight, not soggy, stood well, and dipped well in ketchup (meaning doesn't fold under the weight of the sauce). For $1 more, you can get the sweet potato fries. Maybe next time.

Two sandwiches totaled a little over $19 after tax. Very hearty. 

My only critique is that it is warm in there, at least on a hot day. Aim for a seat by the door.
author: Cindy W.

description: First time at Toast Eatery last week and it's still on my mind, so what can I say, it's a great little brunch place. We actually were planning on going to two other places but due to the packed lines, we decided to give this place a try since the wait was tolerable. Little did we know the food was great. I had the breakfast burrito without meat, which they made up with plenty of eggs inside. The hash brown was delicious! I'll so happy to find a place that serves hash brown with almost all their dishes. =) As for customer service, I thought it was just perfect. The server was super nice and made sure we were good even though we sat in the corner outside. The only reason why I gave them 4 stars instead of 5 is because they served their hot coffees in a tall glass cup. Coffees are meant to be served in a ceramic cup and as a coffee drinker, it just wasn't right. However, the coffee was strong and good. Being that it was our first time there, I would give them 4.6 stars if there was that option and would definitely go back to try something else.
author: Amy T.

description: A nice quiet little diner in Noe Valley. Stopped by here after an evening of photography. Just needed a place to relax, and read. The server was extremely friendly, and their ham and cheese sandwich was marvelous.
author: Gurpreet S.

description: I love eating at Toast! They are fresh, yummy and great for the early birds....My favorite time of the day! I have eaten here multiple times, trying out many dishes and have not been disappointed.
author: Paul R.

description:
The service was slow but very friendly, good thing they had the ballgame on and enough newspaper to distract me while I waited almost 25 minutes for some below average corned beef hash. The prices are high even for good food but paying $11 for something I cooked better when I was 8 is a little insane. Honestly how hard is it to cook breakfast? 

The one good thing was the friendly waitress that never let my water glass run empty. My number one factor in determining a tip.

It is super clean, sadly that's the sign of a bad dinner. When the steel front begins to rust, the floor gets a little stained, and the workers all have messy aprons,  I'll be back.
author: Nick P.

description:
Toast is good.  It's not great.  It's clean and friendly.  The artwork is fun.  My kid always wants to eat there. It's got god-awful lineups on the weekend. 

My kid loves the lox bagel.  I haven't found anything I adore but it's all decent.  Minus one star for charging extra for maple syrup (and I don't even think it's real) when you order the pancakes.
author: Susan M.

description:
As much as I miss Herb's it's nice to have Toast close to my work!

The new location of Toast has been highly anticipated for a while now, so I packed up the family and we went on the grand opening. The inside is decorated very similar to the Church street location. Lots of earthy tones and a warm feel. (Something Herb's lacked)

We all ordered different things for Breakfast and covered all the bases. The food was good. No complaints, just solid breakfast. The service was fine as well. The food took a little longer than I would have hoped for, but we were there within the first hour of the place opening, so I would say all in all it was a solid opening for a place that will succeed in the fickle Noe Valley.

Another thing I noticed was that they have plenty of high chairs and a changing table in the bathroom...they are ready for N.V.!!

I want to give em 5 starts, and hopefully will be able to after they settle in a bit. Like I said, it was a rock solid opening to a place that will be great on 24th street. Getting the food a little slow and the pancakes needing a little work are simple things that I am sure they will correct. 

I'm excited to see what my next eating experience will be like here!!
author: JR H.

description:
I went here for dinner with my honey. While the decor and remodel of the old Herb's is way better, the food seems to be just OK. 

I was pleased that you could order breakfast at 8 pm. I ordered the chicken fried steak. The country gravy was bland which was disappointing as there's nothing like sopping up the gravy with toast and/or smearing over your hash browns. After all, if you're going to eat this much fat and sodium, it'd better be good! The hash browns were fried to a golden crispness and tasty. 

My honey ordered the Nieman ranch burger. It looked good and he liked it. For an additional fee, he got the sweet potato fries which were tasty and not overcooked. 

Service was friendly and attentive, but then again, the restaurant was nearly empty so our server didn't have a lot of distractions.
author: Scott S.

description: Large portions generally don't equate to quality. Not terrible, but not worth a wait.
author: Ian W.

description:
They make a decent omelette...

Waitress was cute...

Nothing else really stands out...
author: Nathan W.

description:
I have been to the Church St Toast several times with not a single complaint.  The Church St location service is prompt, with solid food.  

The 24th St Toast is the EXACT OPPOSITE.  Can I give ZERO stars?  This story is almost too ridiculous to believe.  I walk into the restaurant, and the waitress kindly advises me to order the grilled portobello mushroom sandwich.  So I go ahead and do so, ordering it To Go.  She tells me it will be "10-15min".  So far, so good.

Now pay attention:  She puts the order in, and CHARGES me for the sandwich.  I pay for sandwich via credit card.  ... then, 20 MNUTES LATER, after I inquire about the delay, she comes back from the cooking area and tells me, "The cooks just informed me that we HAVE NO PORTOBELLO MUSHROOMS".   

WTF?!  Are you frikin kidding me? Why didn't you tell me this when I ORDERED IT 20 MINUTES AGO???  She responds, "I don't know, they must be backed up."  What  does that mean?  I was completely shocked. 
  
She not only took my order, placed it, and CHARGED ME for it, but she frikin ADVISED ME to get it.  And 20 MINUTES LATER, she is telling me they don't have it?!!  Is this a joke?  Apparently, it was not a joke, because it got even worse.

After spewing numerous expletives and even getting support from other, equally-stunned patrons in the restaurant, I could see she was totally incompetent and unable to explain her abject failure to perform even the simplest task of her job.  I had no interest in eating there after wasting my time completely.  So I naturally demanded my $ back.  But I was refused even this!  She said, "I can't credit your card back.  Only the manager can do it, because it's 'their' system".  Again, WTF?!!  Who is 'they' and why isn't SHE one of 'them'?  

This was incompetence on a truly colossal scale.
