So basically, 24th St Toast advises customers to order food they don't have, charges them for it, makes them wait interminably before mentioning that they don't have the food, and then refuses to give back the customer's  $, which, last time I checked, can be equated with FRAUD and ROBBERY.

In the end, the manager told this employee to call me at HOME, and they asked me to drive back to pick up a cash reimbursement.  Then they called back AGAIN to tell me they were able to credit the card back.  They even offered me a free meal, but they have no way to keep a record of this, other than my name somewhere at the register.  Is this really 2010?    I am still waiting, with bated breath, to see what happens next.   Never again.  They can keep the free meal.  They will need it.
author: Chuck D.

description: this place is awesome! expect to wait at least 20 minutes if you go on the weekend, but believe me it's worth every minute of that wait. I got a bacon and sausage scrambler with onions and pepper jack cheese with toast and some country style hashbrowns. the portions are huge, and even more importantly, delicious! 5 stars
author: Mike L.

description: I give this Toast 2 stars because the service isn't very good. Of the times I've been there, maybe one waitress is working the floor. They sat us quickly but if you need anything, food, water, or the check you almost have to beg them to bring it. They never come and check up on you to see how you are doing.
author: Nikki G.

description:
I ate at the bar, and it was pretty much cake to get a place there on Thursday night. Good sweet potato fries if those are your thing (they are MY thing). 

Not a lot to say - its a pretty straight forward place. The food was good. Nothing exceptional though...but then again, its a diner, so I wasn't expecting flambee alligator's milk with a side of panda confit. Laid back when I was there, but I typically see a line out the wazoo at this place on weekend mornings. Thats kind of why I went - I figured something cool was happening in there. (Yes, I am one of those people that would look at the nothing in the sky just because the rest of the crowd was. But, I wouldn't stop and stare, I would walk by then take a passing glance over my shoulder all sexy and cool like.) I dunno...it was OK. 

Nice waitress...and she's from Montana...how FUN! That state has a face on it!
author: Sean C.

description: Yum. I'm such a fan. Love going here for breakfast, such a good variety, incredible ingredients (fresh and high quality - I can tell and this is so important for my meal enjoyment). Toast makes my weekend brunches vary happy.
author: Hanan H.

description:
I went for breakfast.  The decor is great and the place is super clean.  I like the chairs and tables - they've done some re-arranging to make more room, it seems.

The food is just ok.  I had very ordinary blueberry pancakes - nothing special at all, and of course, I just can't respect a breakfast place that charges as much as toast does but doesn't serve real maple syrup.  That's a pet peeve of mine.

My friend got a scrambler.  It was ok but processed cheese food on top - ok, maybe it was a slice of American.  The hash browns looked good.

So , it was fine, but I paid a lot for what was not much better than I could get at any diner for much less.
author: Bill V.

description: I decided to stop for breakfast after dropping off a friend at SFO. 24th Street is my old neighborhood, especially the Eureka Valley end. I found the Coast Eatery to be a very enjoyable place, clean, bright with a vintage feel.The Toast Combo/ chicken-apple sausage, eggs over easy, pancakes and a really nice salad. The coffee was the best I remember having at a neighborhood cafe in many years. Excellent, friendly service, reasonable prices.
author: Ray P.

description:
Meet the new Toast, same as the old Toast.  Apologies to The Who, for taking liberties with their lyrics, but I just don't understand why my little 'hood needs two Toasts, that are maybe 10 blocks apart.
 
Though this new 24th Street location boasts a slightly roomier floor plan, the seating practices seem a little more chaotic.  It took way too long to get seated even though there were tables turning over.   They kept waiting for people who'd obviously wandered away to return.  I thought the general rule was "you snooze, you lose"?  No?

In defense of Toast, I am happy to report that their corned beef hash is just as good as the original location.  The hash browns maybe even a bit better...definitely crispier and greasier, if these things matter to you. For me, it's my weakness.  And now I live waaaay too close to it.  Yikes.
author: Becca V.

description:
Came here right after it opened.  Not impressed.  Busy, but no "feel" to the place at all.  Sterile.  Don't let the fancy sign (installed later) fool you.  If a place is going to be packed and a 20 minute wait, I want something other that Noe infants to look at.  Plus, they make me hungry, the fatty little tikes.  I kid - I lose my appetite when the 7th custom stroller nicks my shin.

The food?  Also mediocre.  Maybe they're still working on it.  But as it stands, not worth a walk down to 24th on a Sunday.  There is no more damning statement for a brunch spot.
author: Brian D.

description:
Don't let the name fool you - Toast is open for 3 meals daily.  And while I'm bummed that I didn't get to try Toast's predecessor, Herb's Fine Foods, I think this is a good addition to the restaurants on 24th St.

We did a later Saturday brunch (1:30ish).  Letting the busboy run the wait list wasn't successful, as he wasn't quite sure who was seated, who was waiting, and what I was saying.  And there isn't a clear place as to where one should sign up for the list, or where one should wait once signed up on the list.  Hover in the doorway?  Hover near the plate glass windows on 24th St?  Hover near the curb so as not to loom over window table diners?  Not clear.  Once we were seated, things were pretty darn good.

They should install some ceiling fans - there's not a lot of air movement, and when it's warm outside, it's even warmer inside Toast.  Maybe they're trying to "toast" the patrons - nyuk, nyuk, nyuk.

Had the Church St omelette (sausage, spinach, sun-dried tomato, feta), which was a perfectly prepared omelette, and they were more than happy to substitute potatoes with cottage cheese (thumbs up!)  Also had an iced chai, even though they didn't have it on the menu.  Also had the croissant french toast with fresh fruit - the fruit was delicious, and so was the french toast!  

Our server was extremely friendly (and beautiful), and seemed to keep a pretty cool head among a bustle and noise of the crowd.  Dig the neon clock above the eatery bar, and dig the minimalist (and very clean!) bathroom.

Would go back, and would like to try some of the speciality sandwiches.
author: Evan G.

description: Nobody makes hash browns as crispy and tender, yet buttery as Toast does. Feel the love, 'cuz they dish it out seven days a week. Not just for breakfast, they do lunch and dinner, too. Very good burgers, fries, onion rings. Salads are crisp and tasty. As good as a diner gets.
author: Richard L M.

description:
I am normally not a breakfast person (childhood memories of a parent with poor cooking skills cooking scrambled eggs for dinner on a regular basis still gives me the shivers), but I seem to be up for breakfast at Toast any time of the day!  A new concept for me! And one that speaks to the quality of the establishment indeed!

First off, I have to say that Toast is adorable on the inside.  I feel silly saying this but it is always shiny! It has that old diner feel to it without it being dirty and outdated (like a lot of diner-esque restaurants are).  In fact it looks quite modern and fresh, and is impeccably clean (a huge plus in my book).  

Although the food isn't anything I would deem out of this world, it has always been consistently good.  Anyone who offers Nutella on their menu as a side for pancakes and other delicious pastry style breakfast foods is a winner in my book.

Personal favorite is the mondo sized Breakfast Burrito - a fresh tortilla stuff to the max with eggs, cheese, tons of freshly sliced avocado, salsa, and sour cream.  If that's not enough to fill you up, the delectable dish is served with a hearty serving of crispy old style hash browns.  YUM!

Make sure to go during the week or before nine in the morning if you don't want to have to wait for a table!
author: Ryan H.

description:
Sorry, but I don't understand why everyone mourns the loss of Herb's so much--Toast is a big time improvement! Greasy spoons that actually, um, *have* grease on their spoons do not receive high marks in my book.

But I digress...

Excellent coffee--Peet's is king. Friendly staff and straightforward breakfast food. No silly homefries here--it's all about the hash browns. I have enjoyed every bit of food I've ever had here--from the breakfast to the salads to the chicken cheesesteak. 

Take That, Whiney neighbors of mine!
author: Molly W.

description: Breakfast was IHOP-esque, at best. Pancakes were rubbery, bacon was dessicated, coffee was drinkable I guess. Good service though and we were seated quickly even at 10am on a Sunday. Probably wouldn't eat here again.
author: Josh K.

description:
I found brunch at the old Toast location lacklustre, so I wasn't too thrilled about going to the new location for dinner. 

Well, color me surprised. I ordered the veggie burger, which was actually REALLY good. Crispy on the outside, yet mushy and yummy on the inside. I like that you can switch up the sides(salad/fries/soup/coleslaw I think and maybe a few other options), and I'm always glad to see sweet-potato fries on the menu anywhere. 

The bf on the other hand, didn't love his steak and eggs, but that's what you get for ordering breakfast for dinner. 

They've done a good job redecorating, with a nice nod to Herb's diner on the wall. The servers were good and friendly. We were there early when it was jammed with kiddies, so can't say much about the ambiance. The menu has a good selection of sandwiches, salads and misc. diner food, and of course, breakfast all day. I'm still a giant Meh on the breakfast, but I'd go back for dinner if I needed something quick in the neighborhood.
author: Leah S.

description: Big portions + good prices = great value.  The best chicken fried steak for brunch.  Love the Sirron Norris paintings (check out his gallery on 25th and Valencia).  Downside: Generally pretty crowded.
author: marcie v.

description:
Warning when there is a lot of folks waiting...

My friend and I put my name in and when we came back in 30- mins to check in, they had already called our name and told us we were at the bottom of the list. They didn't tell us they were going to do that and were a touch rude about it.
author: diana h.

description:
Add half a star to the 3. We had a long wait with Sam. Nope Sam wasn't a human friend. Sam was a canine whose dad went to Toast on a rainy day and left Sam standing in the rain. 
The food was OK for me but my husband loved his omlette... so much so that he didn't share it with me. My eggs were ok as was the French toast BUT my chicken sausage was the best I have eaten in awhile. Decent prices for brunch... cute sort of noe place.The hash browns were awesome... delectable really.
author: Pooja S.

description:
Wow. Can't believe how violently some people are reacting to this place. It's not exactly the Pork Store, but then nothing is like the Pork Store... that store... with all kinds of pork... mmmm.... Oh sorry. 

I usually get the chicken fried steak. One time the chicken-steak wasn't very crispy, but normally it's quite delicious. And like another person said, the hash browns are hands down terrific. It's the old fashioned shredded and flattened kind and their's is crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. Also, I find their service to be very fast. You're in and you're out. I have kids and that's how we roll.
author: L. M.

description: Having lived in NYC for over a year, I've come to really appreciate great hashbrowns when I get the chance.  At Toast you can order a dish called the "mountain of hash browns" or something to that effect.  Go crazy and try it out.  The chicken fried steak and italian sausage are awesome.  Apparently you can also get healthy breakfast food here, but I can't imagine why I would ever want to do that.
author: Chad T.

description: We popped in for a late lunch on Friday after Thanksgiving. Not crowded. I had the BLT with turkey bacon, and my daughter had the pulled pork sandwich. Our waitress was friendly, efficient and delivered our food as ordered (eg, no mayo on the sandwich). Portions are LARGE, including the accompanying side salads of field greens. I would definitely return.
author: Beth W.

description: Meah. Cute concept but disappointing food. Hashbrowns are cooked in a thin pancake then cut in square portions for serving. Eggs were overcooked til dry and served in the same sized flat square. I like my breakfast to have a more bountiful feel and be more of messy heap on the plate.  It felt awkward like it was cooked by novices.
author: E. M.

description:
Consistency is important and on this point Toast delivers. They have also moved to fountain soda which is nice for me and the environment.

While what they offer is done well the menu is really is just variations. The space could also use some acoustic help - the large open restaurant gets very loud with even just a few customers.

After being a here a few times I think they definitely deserve a 3-star.
author: Ennis O.

description: We won't go back because they are not sensitive to children.  We were about to order breakfast when my children started staring at the TV screen.  It was a very violent news show and no adults were watching it.  I asked them to stop watching but it is hard to stop looking as a kid.  So I very politely asked the waiter to change the channel (e.g. baseball, golf, classical music concert, anything less violent) and he said the other customers were watching it.  They were not.  Anyway, it wasn't the kind of show you watch while eating breakfast.  If anyone were watching it I am sure they would rather not see all that blood while eating breakfast and would rather watch something more peaceful.  I argued politely but he just seemed annoyed.  So we walked out quietly.  Luckily we hadn't ordered yet so we didn't leave them in a trouble situation.  There are lots of other breakfast places in the area so it will be easy to find a replacement.  Unfortunate.
author: Lancelot C.

description: A friend and I went here for lunch, and the veggie burgers were so so.  For $30, they could have at least toasted the bun and added more cheese.  They were also very skimpy on the fries.  Oh, did I also mention that the server did not smile at all while we were there?
author: Linh D.

description:
One of my favorite breakfast/brunch place EVER!

I've been coming here for 2 years now-to both locations!
I love their hashbrowns!!!! My favorite breakfast dish-joe's scramble.  Oh- and their french toast made with croissants are awesome too!  Sometimes I'll get a side salad and their poppyseed dressing is to die for....

I don't mind the wait for a table at Toast.  I usually don't wait more then 20mins.
author: Alvin M.

description:
Loud, cramped, food is mediocre at best.

After waiting a long time we were brought in and shown a table that neither of us would be able to squeeze through without upsetting the people at the next table. Another couple who were slim, decided that they couldn't either. After several more minutes, they found one man who was willing to squeeze in.

Finally we were seated at the bar. Coffee was not offered. When she asked if we were ready to order we finally got our coffee. The coffee was fine and very hot. However, being at the bar, I wouldn't think we'd have problems with refills, but my boyfriend's cup was left empty for quite a while. Pancakes were edible, but had to use a knife to cut them. The hashbrowns were like Ore-ida pattys. 

For 6 small pancakes, 3 strips of bacon. 1 patty of hash browns, and 2 coffees, we spent 23 dollars minus the tip.

I don't plan to go back.
author: Elly B.

description: Good little breakfast place in Noe Valley.   Hasbrowns really good.  Damn fine cuppa coffee.   Nothing amazingly amazing, but everything good.  I go whenever I'm in the neighborhood for breakfast.
author: Travis B.

description: Meh is right! Toast looks cute and jolly, but it's more like an overpriced deli with sloppy service and mediocre food. Like the toast on the wall, but meh meh meh.
author: Sara W.

description:
There are a myriad of reasons I really enjoyed my parfait:

- I literally walked from Diamond Heights to get here (one missed bus after another....)
- It was noon and I was starved
- Parfait was gigantic
- Parfait included quite a variety of fruit, including boysenberries, a rare add
- It was almost one by the time I got home to enjoy it

Almost five on the parfait alone, and I did love the new Toast space. At $8 and change, just a bit pricey, but still recommended.
author: Jason B.

description:
"All around the country coast to coast,
People always say what do you like most,
I don't wanna brag i don't wanna boast,
I always tell 'em I like toast.

Yeah TOAST! Yeah TOAST"

-'Toast Song' Excerpt from the Bob and Tom Show (Chicago)

Pros: I like toast and theirs is good.  AMAZING quality for simple diner food.  I am a very picky hash brown person, and their do theirs right!  Fun atmosphere in a really cute neighborhood.  Wait staff is all super-friendly and attentive. 

Cons: Parking can be rough and there is often a wait.  The crowds also tend to be a little noisy as well so don't expect an intimate conversational experience.  Also, that "AMAZING quality" of their food that I mentioned... yeah, you have to pay a little bit extra for it.  For a diner its really pricey.  

Must Haves: Corned Beef Hash!

Mmmmm
author: Nicholas S.

description: Good breakfast lunch. I ordered a toast combo and it didn't have toast. Our waitress was anything but friendly or helpful. People rave about this place but I can get a $15 breakfast anywhere.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I hadn't heard too much (or anything really) about this place but, as we walked by on the way to the Noe Valley Farmer's Market I took notice that it was filled with people and more waiting to in outside.

The hubby, kid and I were hungry after walking around and decided on Toast simply because of the popularity of the place.

Not bad.

I had the BTLA which was just the right amount of all the ingredients and a rather generous portion of fries. The husband had the crispy chicken sandwich was just as listed. Good crispy chicken in a bun. Nothing fancy, simple and good. He went with the salad option and it was a nice big portion as well. (kid nibbled from our plates)

For what it's worth, it was an okay place to have a bite.
author: J B.

description:
I'm surprised that Toast ain't averaging higher ... I love it.

Friendly, prompt service (essential for hangover recovery), great village-y people watching - both inside and out,  delish Mr. Espresso coffee, and dreamy lox beigels and omelets. Not too greasy. Definitely higher on the "rabbit food" fruit and salad side than the average brunch spot.

I wish there were more independent bruncheries like this.
author: Richard B.

description: Amazing french toast!! great and friendly workers
author: Joe S.

description: Toast is a nouveau greasy spoon without the grease.  Also, with out the salt.  The hash browns, while perfectly golden brown on the inside lacked any type of seasoning.  I tried the Noe Valley scramble and it reminded me of a diner that I went to with my mom when I was eleven.  Nostalgic and very hearty.  I also tasted the buckwheat pancakes.  I expected some dry hoecakes but these were moist, rich and filling.  I'm definitely coming back for these and bringing my own maple syrup a la Seinfeld.  But what drew me in was that they had a huge tv that was playing la Copa.  Viva Portugal!
author: Monica L.

description: The food is fine, just very overpriced.  Their grilled cheese is not worth $9.
author: M D.

description:
Really good pancakes with friendly service.

On 24th Street, a real SF neighborhood street with lots of cool shops.
Shpatzir around after bkfast.
author: Alan R.

description: This place is GREAT!  It's one of my favorite breakfast spots.  The lunch is good too.  i have not a single complaint about them.  Food is great and fresh and the staff is friendly, can't ask for more.
author: Sheree A.

description:
I'm trying very hard not to judge Toast simply by comparison to its true diner predecessor, Herb's (aka "Herb's Fine Foods"), which I miss dearly, but I'm finding that next to impossible to avoid.  It's not just that Toast occupies the same physical space that Herb's did for how many decades, but it is also that Toast aspires to follow in the footsteps of the American diner tradition, but just can't pull it off.

Yes, Toast has ketchup and those little jam and jelly packets at each table, and it also has seating at the counter.  How oh-so-charming.  That must make it a diner, right?

One fundamental problem here is that whoever designed the 24th Street outlet of the Toast chain seems to have been convinced that certain "upgrades," such as the flat-screen monitor tuned to CNN; those horrific decorative gleaming plastic toast replicas on the wall (yes, we know you're called "Toast," we get it) that are evidently supposed to evoke a graffiti-esque edge; the intrusively loud background music; or the sorry little wine/beer/Italian soda shelf behind the counter, either have any intrinsic attractiveness or value to them, or somehow are true to the diner experience.  But in trying to somehow be both a diner and a "millennial upgrade," Toast succeeds at neither; it has "faux" written all over it.

The second fundamental problem is that the food is somewhat tasteless.  We went there because, to their credit, they are one of the few places to be found in San Francisco that still serves hash browns (as opposed to home fries).  But the hash browns arrived in a perfectly flat and rectangular shape, as if straight out of microwave-ready packaging.  And the taste matched their appearance.  At Herb's, I remember seeing someone actually frying up the hash browns on a grill, and actually having them look and taste as if they had been made by a human at a grill.  Maybe the Jetsons like bland hash browns with perfectly formed straight edges; not me.

Finally, the pricing is a little on the steep side for what you get.  A side of bacon, which turned out to be three strips thereof, was $3.95.  At Herb's, you could have gotten eggs, hash browns, toast, *and* bacon for about $6-7.  I paid about $11 for the same combination this morning.  Now that's progress.

For those of you who aspire to eat in the New Millenium, go to Savor - which I also like, but for different reasons and because it's not trying to be something it isn't.  For those who want to eat at a diner, I'd unfortunately recommend going someplace besides Toast.  Long live Herb's.
author: moosedog i.

description:
This place opened a while ago and the number of people waiting and blocking the sidewalk out front always bothered me when trying to navigate on weekend mornings.  But I figured I'd try it out since I wanted breakfast and it was late in the day.

The method by which you express your interest in getting a table is kind of haphazard: you need to write your own name down.  This isn't really mentioned anywhere and we kind of had to figure it out ourselves.  Once we did get assigned a table, it took longer than I'd have liked to have it bussed.  I was expecting the service to be more attentive, another waiter would would help, but considering how cramped it is more people would have made it worse.

The food is  acceptable, but there's not much distinctive about it, generic California diner fare (ie avocado in some dishes).  I might hit this place up again late in the day if there is no wait and I fancy some uninspired eats.
author: Andy B.

description:
3 stars today, with no hangover cure needed
4 stars if I needed a cure for a hangover

Everything on the plate had grease attached to it, minus the  - pardon the pun - Toast.

Eggs - Greasy
Hashbrowns - Greasy
Bacon - Triple Dog Dare You Greasy

For two breakfasts, two cups of coffee - $20.00, no complaints on that front.  Coffee gave me a giddy-up in my step, thats for sure.
author: Jason I.

description: Toast is better at the restaurant than via take-out. The take-out portions seem SMALL and lame. Dining in the restaurant is pleasant. The staff is friendly and responsive, the food is high quality but that doesn't mean the dishes are as high quality, some dishes are a little disappointing...
author: Eliz M.

description: Why do I always forget about this place? It's walking distance from my house and never fails to please. Nevertheless, I always end up wandering around my immediate neighborhood, cursing the fact that Boogaloos (GROSS) is the only vegan breakfast joint in the area, before I remember Toast! Anyway, there are several vegan options that are really yummy and the service is always great. The only downside is sometimes there is quite a wait, but hey, we're in SF, all good places have a wait!
author: Susie D.

description:
The menu has all the classics, but the prices are bumped up -- stinks for the customer but hey, someone's gotta pay for that flat-screen behind the bar.

I had a $9 lox bagel (adequate, nothing special), plus $3.50 sweet potato fries that weren't even salted. Crispy but talk about *bland.* If you want awesome sweet potato fries go to Catch in the Sunset. They do use salt.

On another occasion, I ordered a 2-egg breakfast which came with toast and hash browns. The toast was tasty (woulda been ironic had it not) and the hash browns were AWESOME. Still though, I left feeling hungry. There was nothing traditionally diner-like about my dish's small proportions.

Service was pleasant enough, but the second time I went, my server kept doing drive-by's and dashing off before I could have a chance to make a request or ask a question. So I guess, service was on the inattentive side that time.

This place is packed by 12 noon -- even on weekdays, so if you don't want to deal with a lunch time wait, get there by 11:45am. Also, be prepared to hear every sordid detail of your neighboring table's lover's quarrel.  For some reason, I felt vaguely guilty for "eavesdropping," but it couldn't be helped. They pack us in there like sardines. 

Both times we went, I think we were like the only straight group in there. The Castro boys love this place.

I dunno, I could take it or leave it. For heartier portions, better food, more attentive service, and a much cheaper bill (albeit less slickster), I'd rather go to Manor Cafe in West Portal.
author: SfMom O.

description: The food is usually pretty good, but nothing special. I'd rather go to Savor or Haystack if I was in Noe Valley. I was there once and the sewar was all messed up, which made a very bad odor throughout the dining room. The coffee has tasted over two days old at times, although I was there last night and had a damn good iced coffee.
author: Marty F.

description:
I miss Herb's but Toast is a nice upgrade.

I recommend the grilled eggplant sandwich = a super yummy veggie treat.

Will try the milkshakes at the next visit.
author: Shannon B.

description: Hideous does not begin to express the attitude dished out at this pretentious so-called 'eatery'.  Sneering little white chick sucking her teeth at the gall of two customers sitting at the counter Before Their Names Were Called!!!!!! We were next on the list, and I verbally checked in- "okay if we sit here?" to which I recieved a cursory "yeah" until Blondie the counter Nazi noticed us: she glared, she scolded, she condescended.  We took ourselves to Diamond Heights and saw our friends at Choice Yakiniku. Never again- You are Toast, toast, in our book.
author: victoria c.

description:
I debated giving this review a one star.  Considering the hype and wait, food was not memorable and borderline bland.  

Friends who live in the neighborhood are mystified why people were waiting to eat there for Sunday brunch when there are so many tastier places close by.
author: Victory V.

description:
Toast Eatery Noe Valley can be summed up as a eatery of contradictions.

The good:

- Boudin Bakery breads.  Ok, a little commercial, but a local business
- Niman Ranch meats
- Fair trade certified & organic coffees
- Organic fruits and produce, when available
- Compostable paper takeaway cartons 

Given the above, one feels like Toast is making efforts to serve healthier food ingredients, until ...

The bad:

- Smuckers brand jelly.  The second ingredient: high fructose corn syrup, the third ingredient: corn syrup.  Uh, where's the organic jelly?
- Heinz ketchup.  Yup, same ingredients as in Smuckers
- C&H sugar.  Ultra refinded and would probably satisfy the former Herb's crowd, but they also offer a more natural alternative, Sugar In The Raw brand turbinado sugar
- Regular iodized table salt.  What, no Fleur de sel?

Overall, Toast is a nice alternative to other Noe Valley breakfast restaurants and the late closing time of 10:00 pm is a welcome addition to our street of strollers and pups.  Typical breakfast fare, such as eggs benedict, scrambles, pancakes and corn beef hash are served, in addition to hamburgers, salads and sandwiches for lunch and dinner.  

Service was spotty on our visit, with delays in taking our order, refilling our water glasses and removing our dishes, but it certainly is a step above the former tenant - Herb's Fine Foods.  The building has been glamed up quite a bit with shiny metal trimmings on the exterior.  The only reminder of Herb's is the original Victorian mosaic tile at the front door and perhaps the counter service, though I miss the horseshoe counter of Herb's, it was pretty unique.  A tribute to Herb's, a hipster style hand drawing above the restroom door in the shape of a piece of toast, reminds diners of the former restaurant that occupied this space for so many years.  An additional 5 drawings line the wall with San Francisco cityscapes.

Uh, what's up with that distracting flat screen?
author: Rafael R.

description:
Finally a replacement for the late Herb's "Fine" Foods (see my other review).
If you like funky vinyl booths, greasy spoon decor and greasy spoon food, then I guess this won't fill the void.

The place that used to be Herb's has been completely gutted and rebuilt, with a new hardwood floor (somehow I don't miss the old linoleum floor) clean new tables, clean chairs, clean kitchen, and, unfortunately, a big (but clean!) TV behind the counter. I could do without the stupid TV, but on my first visit today the service was good, and the "Noe Valley" (how apt) omelet consisting of bacon, avocado, cheddar (which I declined), and eggs, of course, was pretty good.

I do miss the Eggs Blackstone that Herb's used to have, and of course the prices are about 50% higher, and there's slightly less food (hmm, almost starting to miss it now...)
but the new surroundings make up for it. Did I mention it's clean? I'm not an OCD clean freak either - just contrasting it with Herb's.

Oh, and I did go late on a Wednesday morning so there were no weekend brunch crowds to make me wait.
But what's up with the TV?
I go to eat, not watch CNN, or heaven forbid(!) ESPN -- can't vouch for their showing that channel but that would really suck for me.
author: Peter X.

description:
First off, let me just say that I'm not one of those 'reviewers' who just wants to bash a place.  I want my review to be realistic, not mean or spiteful.  I hate how there are SO many cowards who hide behind their words (or I should say their insecurity), afraid to actually communicate their opinions in person.  Because just bitching about it here or even saying nice things (without conveying it to the business itself) will not allow the business to grow....period.

That said, I had just an OK time here.  The food was like something I'd have at a friends for brunch...comfortable but so-so.  The atmosphere was average and exactly what you'd pay for.  It's a busy place with a wait and the staff were on top of it all.  I can't say they weren't friendly but they weren't super happy, chipper people either.  Again, my experience was OK.  

BTW, I did actually share this (not in such detail) with the host, in hopes that they can become a better place.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Pros: The food is great, traditional breakfast food. The waiters are friendly. It's best to come on a weekday.

Cons: Gets very loud after 9:00, and it's annoying because it's in such a small space. Arrive by 8:30.

All in all, it's a good breakfast place if you come early (best by yourself or with one other person because you won't get a seat for 30 minutes if you're in a group) and are willing to spend a little (just a little) extra money.
author: Catherine L.

description:
Yummy food. Great service. Friendly atmosphere. What's not to like? I'll be a regular...
The person working the door/wait list could be a bit more friendly.
author: Tom L.

description: Okay were do I start I took my mother for dinner and we order the breakfast my Mother told the Fu$#@#$$ waitress she wanted her eggs well done not runny but the waitress responded with a rude question Whattttttttttttt    come on now you need us customers to go in pay the bill and tip so you can pay your rent, credit card, plastic surgery, your American Idol t-shir etc. But what you  you really need is a attitude adjustment here's a concept be nice smile I know it's hard and we know about the Noe valley attitude before you we had Herbs and the staff were highly nice... hope you take my suggestion and be nice..... The food was good....
author: jerry p.

description: Great diner breakfast! We prefer this location to the one nearer to our house on Church St. Something about the atmosphere and cooks at this location seems better to us, but the one on Church has outdoor seating so you can bring your dog if you like to that one. The hashbrowns are great as are every egg dish I've ordered. The croissant french toast is a favorite of the kiddies too. The fact that the serve breakfast all day isn't too shabby either. The burgers are supposed to be great here too, but we can't seem to get off the breakfast menu whenever we go :)
author: Artina M.

description: I am a long time resident of Noe Valley, actually on 24th Street less than two blocks away from Toast. I would like to preface this review by saying that I have eaten here quite a few times. The only reason I periodically return is to see if they have improved their service and the quality of their food. It is my humble opinion that they have not made any improvements from the day they first opened, which is to say the food and service stinks. Why does this diner have make the patron ask for Splenda? Each table and counter place has other sugar substitutes and sugar packets, but you have to ask for Splenda. What a stupid policy. Now as for the food. If I could rate this place with a negative star, I would, but Yelp doesn't give me that option. I could probably write a short story regarding the lousy food, but I will try to contain myself. First let me say, what they call scrambled eggs would be better characterized as a fried egg patty, over cooked, and topped with food that sometimes is nearly unidentifiable. The hash brown patties must have been cooked on a device where temperatures must approach those of the sun's surface. Toast people, turn down your grill a bit. Anyone who orders French Toast, be prepared to have toast that is browned that has no taste, and the egg batter with which it is supposed to have some vanilla flavoring has no flavoring whatsoever. They could at least dust the "French Toast" with some confectioner's sugar. At least the taste buds could identify a flavor of sorts. I don't want to waste too much of your time or mine, but suffice it to say that the lunch fare is on par with the breakfast food, just not worth a visit. My view is not from just from one sitting. Since I live in the neighborhood toast is very convenient for me, hence my periodic visit with the hope the place improves. Since Toast is usually very busy on the weekends, I guess the proprietor(s) don't feel the need to improve its food and service. May I suggest they at least taste their tasteless food and perhaps make a change. One last thought, for the life of me, I can't understand the continued patronizing of this diner.  I have always thought San Franciscans had a far more discriminating palette. Even Herbs Fine Foods, which once occupied the place before Toast, wasn't all that great, was better than Toast.
author: Barry V.

description: I took my mother here when she was visiting last month and she really liked it.
author: Mitsi M.

description: Always busy and humming with locals. Great menu with all possible breakfast combinations.
author: Mike P.

description:
"My milk shake brings all the boys to the yard,
and they"re like
it's better than yours,
damn right it's better than yours,
I can teach you,
but I have to charge"

Staff (Jessica, Trystin, Colleen, Tracy, Emily, Megan and Rosa) are super rad, milkshakes rule, breakfast all day/night.... Werd!
author: Nick D.

description: Early Friday morn my son and I went in for breakfast. I ordered oatmeal and she pancakes. Oatmeal was worse than bland. Tasted like old socks and wasn't served with milk or sugar. I don't usually complain but when I did the server nonchalantly said "well it's instant.". What?? $6 for instant oatmeal? Then my son pushed away his pancakes. I took a bite and they were rubbery. On paying I mentioned the less than half eaten pancakes tasted rubbery as though they were microwaved. The server said "oh no I saw them cook them. Oh maybe the grill wasn't hot enough. "  the food was gross the server could care less and it's pricey. Don't waste your time or money.
author: Christina g.

description: Good for brunch! the breakfast burrito is excellent!
author: Alaina I.

description: very good food, service was attentive and easy going. definitely a place ill re-visit.
author: Moises M.

description: Yummy food, large servings, good prices, sweet servers, easy parking.  What's not to love?  Their omelets/scramblers, french toast, and hash browns are all delicious.  (I haven't sampled other items.)
author: Ellen S.

description:
4.5 stars, potential 5 if I have a great return trip.

I was leery going into the experience. My friend raved about it but I tend to lean on the side of the Yelp community. Can't blame me, right Yelpers? For once, I'm going against the grain. I had one hell of a fantastic meal at Toast! Granted, the wait was a bit painful but with enough nagging (apologies to the host - my friend is an east coaster!), we eventually were seated by the window. I ordered a cup of joe and the lox scramble with hash browns and wheat toast. I don't know what it is but the combination of lox and cream cheese is just heaven to me. Scramble that together and... sorry, I'm going to need a moment. Toast took my favorite combo to a whole new level. Not only were there huge chunks of salmon but they also threw in generous amounts of avocado and tomato! I'll be surprised if I ever try another dish on the menu. And the hash browns? What can I say - crispy, crunchy, awesome.
author: Susan L.

description: I like this place fine, as long as its an off time of day and  I get a salad.  They do produce a lovely salad.  As for the sandwiches, I wish their cooks would head to Ike's, Mr. Pickle's, or Molinari to find out what a truly great sandwich tastes like.  With a name like Toast one would expect the sandwiches to be their best items, but I have stopped ordering them there because they are so very bland.  I will say however, that the service is stellar.  So on a late Sunday afternoon, when I happen to be in a mood for a salad, they are a four star restaurant.  Problem is, there is nothing on the menu worth waiting in line for (unlike say, Ike's).
author: Liz R.

description:
Look, the bottom line is that this place is a diner.  The food is good, not great, but certainly not bad by an means (I would say above average...which is a winner if you're in SF).  If you're looking for a yummy greasy meal or some decent breakfast, you've come the right place.

It is a little pricey, but it's also a clean place with decent service, which I'd rather have over a nasty greasy diner.  People get pissed if they have to wait, but that's part of coming here...deal with it.  Go across the street and get some coffee at Bernies (mmmm) and wait patiently.
author: Michael S.

description: I've had a lot of corned beef hash in my life and I must say that Toast's ranks the highest on my list. Also their hash browns are cooked to perfection, extra crispy on the outside and nice and fluffy on the inside.
author: Dexter C.

description: Ran across this place on a random Saturday night. Feeling like breakfast,  I had a belgian waffle with strawberries+blueberries. Fantastic food and fast, straight-forward service.
author: Mike M.

description: This place is a good stand by for me.  I enjoy the French Burger and the Noe Scramble.  Nothing too fancy, the place is very reasonable with pricing and very clean.
author: Blake J.

description: 4 months later and the wait's not getting any shorter and the service isn't any quicker!  GO HOME.
author: Kelly H.

description: I like it! Nice little diner. The sandwiches are yum. They have sweet potato french fries. I usually get the turkey sandwich. They do serve beer. The staff has been friendly, helpful. There are plenty of tables. Unfortunately, it's always packed on Sundays, but that happens to most good restaurants for brunch.
author: Heidi L.

description: Staff was short and dismissive. Way overpriced food too! Had an omelette the first time and the ham and cheese sandwhich the second time. There are better places to spend your money in Noe.
author: Addy K.

description: Classic simple diner style food.  Very yummy and reasonably priced.  Food counter and tight table seating otherwise. Go Here!
author: Melissa B.

description: The ambiance is nice, but the service and food is mediocre. Don't be fooled by the waiting diners outside.
author: Tim B.

description: I give Toast high marks for their benedicts, omelets, and hash browns. Their Hollandaise is just right - not too thin, but not gooey.  The coffee is no great shakes, but perfectly serviceable as diner coffee goes.  Their hash browns are terrific with that perfect crispy golden crust on top that so few places get right any more.  I go back often since it's so close, but I always go when there's no line. It's a fine, local diner, but not a destination brunch spot worth queueing up 45 minutes for.
author: Kaley D.

description: service was friendly but my main let down was the food.  $10.50 for a cold platter of breakfast; hash brown (burnt), toast (cold), corn has (cold), eggs (cold)...... did i mention we sat inside?  i would rather walk 1 block down and eat at savor!
author: Mimi S.

description:
I was excited at the modern style and menu selections of this new location - a definite upgrade to the aging looks of this chain's history.  I ordered the French Toast Slam (which apparently has been renamed the Toast Combo) and my friend ordered the Ham and Cheese Omelet (which is now called the godfather).  Unfortunately the prices of the new menu are much higher and my French Toast Slam came with a choice of sausage or bacon - not both.  The eggs were even more watery than usual and I wasn't sure if the french toast was made with bread or if they had used recycled cardboard in an attempt at being green.  I marinated my pork sausages in syrup in an attempt to make them edible, but even then they remained too hard to cut through with the knife provided.  My friend's Ham and Cheese Omelet came with Italian sausage instead of ham, which would have been a nice upgrade if it didn't taste like burned bacon.  We each had a large orange juice but it seems that while they've increased the price to $3.50, they've downgraded from minute maid to the generic powdered substitute.

All in all I'm unimpressed with the changes to the familiar restaurant design and menu.  I think I'll stick to their 816 Mission St location if I'm in the mood for bad food as at least the food tastes marginally better there and there isn't a line.  Maybe I would have been happier had I determined what the new incarnation of Moons over my Hammy is, but I think the only way I would give them a second chance is if they bring back the $2.99 Grand Slam.
author: Andrew N.

description: Can someone please clarify for me why people lose their minds over this place? I pass by it on the weekends, and Toast is consistently packed. Before it came to 24th street, I had heard a lot of hype about it, and was excited. I've given it several chances, and am equally as unimpressed every time. Pancakes have a bisquick taste, food seems generic and runny, and it's a diner that lacks diner charm- you might as well go to ihop or denny's.
author: Kristen M.

description: I would just like to say that this is an amazing restaurant with amazing service. My friend and I come here once in a while for a quick bite and always leave satisfied. We always have the same server. Aria. She is extremely kind, friendly, and makes the experience great. Thanks for always being the best service I have. :)
author: Kevin B.

description: Seriously nothing special. Had the chicken fried steak -- it was literally identical to Cracker Barrel.
author: Adam Z.

description: not bad at all. just had lunch at the noe valley 24th st location and it was better than i expected. i figured their lunch would at least be as good as squat and gobble (which i would also say is "not bad at all"). it was better -- or, rather, at least i thought toast's reuben sandwich and burger were better. they said their corned beef was made in-house - no idea how one makes corned beef, but it sure was damn tasty, while also giving off that fresh, organic texture and flavor you might expect from something declared as being made "in-house". one might call it above average diner food. service was good/fast. price was fine for 2 people (by sf standards). will go again. will tell friends to try the reuben.
author: Patrick W.

description: I don't get why everyone doesn't xoxo Toast!!  My roommate and I love it.  I wouldn't go with a big group b/c it's small and cramped, but that's really the only negative.  I don't mind waiting - I kind of assume that's part of going to brunch in SF.  The Greek omelet, fruit salad, scramblers, coffee -- all yummilicious.
author: C K.

description: Even with its nice space and great service this was still the worst breakfast I've ever had in SF. The food was bland and greasy. Terrible hashbrowns. I would have rather eaten in a smoke-filled truckstop Denny's.
author: Jesse W.

description:
I wonder if I'm the only resident of Noe Valley who does NOT miss Herbs Fine Foods (which was in the same location). Not that I have anything against greasy spoon diners, but the food there was far-and-away the absolute worst breakfast fare around. It did have a certain charm, I'll give you that, and the fact that it was in operation for decades was kind of cool, but man the food was tasteless and greasy.

As for Toast, well the food is okay, but rather bland. I've been four times with friends and we always have to ask for Tabasco to spice things up a bit. The menu is huge, but as many have said, not very interesting.

However, I love the decor, and the service is quite good. And, having another option in the hood is a really good thing. (I did not consider Herbs and option).
author: Lucky C.

description: This place is right below my friends' apartment in San Francisco. It always seems busy and crowded. We happened to pop in during an odd time (4pm=dinner or lunch?) and were lucky to find the restaurant almost empty. The inside decor is nice - the feeling of an old diner (counter and stools and all) but more modern and sleek. The food was pricier than I was expecting, but the portions were pretty big. I had the country friend steak, which was pretty tasty. I especially liked the hash browns, which were perfectly shredded and golden. The coffee was good too. I'd go there again!
author: Somer P.

description: Good brunch spot - especially like the hash browns with the eggs. Friendly staff, nice ambience, cool artwork, family & yuppie haven. The food is good, though not anything out of the ordinary. Also, the portion size is small compared to the prices. I don't think it justified the long wait.
author: Shweta V.

description: I can always count on good breakfast at this cute little joint. There golden crispy hashbrowns are the best!  Weekends are bit crowded so I often go on weekdays. Good place to eat breakfast alone, sit by the window and people/dog watch.
author: Kaori T.

description: Busy place in Noe valley.  I wanted regular fried eggs but they don't make them that way as the waitress said they only had them scrambled in with ham/bacon or in an omelet.  The scrambled thing was good and plenty with lots of meat in it and the hash brown fairly good as well.  No jam served with toast and no milk/cream on table for coffee.  One tub of butter for toast. It's nice cause it's not fancy at all, so it's uber casual.  I gave it 2 stars because truthfully I have experienced much better elsewhere.  My friend said people wait in line in hoards on the weekend, but that's what some people like to do.  There are so many places in SF. to eat, I hardly ever go back anywhere altho I used to love Askew on upper Market but that's something else now.
author: William G.

description: I went to Toast for a quick dinner on a Wednesday night, and it was just right.  I had the French Dip sandwich (great) and the Cheddar Broccoli Soup (so-so).  The wait staff was friendly, and the pecan pie hit the spot -- although I wouldn't say outstanding.  (The waitress said the cupcakes were her favorite.) I recommend this place for a good, any-night-of-the-week dinner.  Although I hear their brunch is excellent!
author: Jennifer P.

description: Our little family has enjoyed their breakfasts twice now.  The wait can be a bit depending day and time.  The service was good.  The food was great.  The kids love their chocolate chip pancakes.  Their omelettes and hamburgers are delicious, too!
author: Christina T.

description: The Denver scramble was pretty good.  They gave me a refill on the water for my tea without prompting, which was nice.  The decor seems clean and pretty.
author: Niniane W.

description: The ambiance brought me to this place due to it's warm welcoming and just how cozy it looked. Now for the food, the fresh fruit was excellent and the hashbrows... Best I've tasted. Their Denver omelette was excellent!
author: San S.

description: I give this place 3 to 4 stars. I went at an off time so there was no wait. I ordered an omelet which came with toast and hash browns. The omelet and hash browns were very tasty. The toast was nothing special, however.
author: Meredith G.

description: I actually find the 10am wait to be about average for most of the big breakfast joints in the city (Ella's, Boogaloo's, etc.)   The service is good and the food is reliably good.  I just don't feel like doing backflips about eggs and toast and other basics that I can enjoy at home within 10 mins. of my first hunger pangs... I guess it all depends on if I'm in the mood to dine out or to cook something, like bacon, that I probably wouldn't manage to put together at home.   Overall, a good, reliable breakfast place if you're looking to go out and want good service and are willing to wait a bit.
author: Maria C.

description: Good food but it is packed during brunch on weekends. It's a bit small but the service is quick and friendly.
author: Joe D.

description: Same menu and great service as the other Toast, just not as far out. Nice homage to Herb's in the cute toast-shaped decor. The place is a decent size and hopefully they can eventually offer outdoor seating... it can get rather warm inside. Viva La Toast!
author: Aaron L.

description: Eh.  Rubbery pancakes, bad fries (frozen?), runny salad dressing, and gravy with a strange taste (from a box mix?).
author: Shin C.

description:
After rave reviews from my friends, I decided to give this place a go.  My short stack of blueberry pancakes were crammed with fresh blueberries and had a pretty decent "mouthfeel."  However, my friend's "hot link sausage" was a surprise, as it was not really a breakfast sausage, but rather a spicy hot dog.  That is what a hot link is, but she wasn't expecting that for breakfast. Lesson learned. However, my other pal devoured her extended buffet of scrambled eggs, bacon, and belgian waffle with strawberries. The orange juice was good too, and the bottomless coffee was nice and hot, which is not always what you get in places like this.  Overall, my breakfast experience was a nice one, and it didn't hurt that we had a cute server.

4.5 Star. Very Enjoyable.
author: Danny D.

description: I just returned from my honeymoon and had breakfast at Toast this morning with my neighbor. It is so nice to see so many families with kids at Toast. I am expecially happy to see so many single men ( married or not, who knows) with kids. This Noe Valley and 24th Street is just wonderful! The staff at Toast are so nice and so accomodating to everyone! I just love this neighborhood!
author: Cathy S.

description:
Absolutely the blandest most boring breakfast food I've ever eaten. 

My daughter had the hash brown hill, which sounded great on paper, but was so bland that my daughter, who loves all the ingredients, couldn't even finish it.  I tried it and it seemed they hadn't put even the most basic salt or pepper on it. We were craving ANYTHING that would give it flavor! 

I had the tofu scramble. There were no seasonings at all on it. Absolutely awful.

Also, the waitress was very unfriendly.

I would never waste my money at this place again. Sigh.
author: ellyn h.

description: Previously I have eaten at Toast on Church St. and the service and food was great!  Yesterday my son & I ate at the Noe Valley restaurant and it was AWFUL!  I ordered eggs w/corned beef hash and the hash was stringy/ropey and dry and there were practically no potatoes in the mixture.  It must have been weeks old.  I paid $34 including the tip and I felt I should not have left a tip either the waitress interrupted my conversation while I was obviously talking.  I won't be back!
author: Donna S.

description: So - So.  The pear salad is good, and the hamburgers look decent.  Not my first choice for Noe Valley take-out but kudos for staying open till 10 and having a clean, hip atmosphere.  This place has potential.
author: Justin C.

description: The food is really good, but not sure it's worth the wait.  I've been going there since they opened, and the service is horrible.  I can't understand how they run a business this way.  On an average weekend, you can find a long wait, and tables can be empty, yet no one has cleaned them.  Also, when you first sit down, it takes waitresses at least 20 minutes to come to your table.  Where is the management in this place???  This place would never survive in NY.
author: Debra J.

description: decent food but nothing to rave about. the croissant french toast is exactly as it sounds. the croissant french toast at Chloe's is more crisp and just much better. the cornedbeef hash is dry but i kind of like it that way. a decent brunch but i wouldn't rush to go again.
author: Regina C.

description: I understand why other reviewers are dinging Toast. I simply will not wait in line for breakfast or brunch. However, I've been to Toast several times during the week for lunch or a late dinner. No wait = good experience. It's better-than-average diner food, and it fits the bill when I'm in the mood for comfy American food.
author: Lee S.

description: Pretty good. I love to come here for dinner and eat pancakes which are very delicious. Always good coffee and specialty coffee. Service is always good. No outside seating. If you love breakfast come here or Savor.
author: julie q.

description: It was my birthday and I was undecided what to do with my day, because I was a bit tired. There were no good movies playing and it was a nice day out--so i walked to Noe Valley, because I really wanted a waffle and a cup of coffee. I had only eaten there once before and i had posted a previous review. It was quiet, but there was no menu on the window--so i asked the server if I could look at the menu and she was very nice. I decided to stay and get my meal. They were very attentive to me. I placed my order and my coffee was brought right out--it tasted good and it perked me up. I relaxed and enjoyed it. Shortly afterward, they brought out my waffle and it was awesome--it was actually huge, hot, freshly made and covered with mounds of beautiful red strawberries dusted off with powdered sugar. The waffle had the perfect crispness when I cut into it and was absolutely delicious. Jessica was a wonderful waitress--gave me my coffee and wrote happy birthday on my receipt. Lydia and Irene was super nice and friendly. They are all genuinely into their job--they are all great.....and they made my day
author: alexandria s.

description: I can't figure out why this place is so popular.  We were there this morning early, before the crowds.  The food is completely uninspired.  Tasteless hash browns, terribly over cooked sausage.  Boring!
author: laurel t.

description: Been here several times for breakfast and lunch. Will only go though if there's no one in line. The food is so-so but the coffee great. I live around the corner so it's convenient. The hash browns are a problem, tasteless and greasy. Some of the scrambles and omelets are good. Hamburgers so-so. Wait staff friendly but sometimes you feel ignored. Can't get out of there for under $15 with coffee tax and tip.
author: Steven V.

description:
yum, yum, yum! not sure why there are so many "eh" reviews. i've eaten here quite a few times and everything (with one exception, see below) has been really good. 

their salads are uber-fresh and delicious, and there are a wide range of ingredient options. so many sandwiches, though i usually get the philly chicken sandwich because it's just so damned good. and their sweet potato fries are really good. one day i ordered a grapefruit juice and got an entire PINT of fresh-squeezed for $3.75--unheard of in this $$ city. my friends and bf have really enjoyed their meals, too--and my bf says the toast is, in fact, really good. (i'm trying to get up the nerve to try their corned beef hash, as kate's kitchen's is so amazing i'm afraid that nothing else could measure up.)

my only disappointment was the belgian waffle, which i finally gave in and ordered. it seemed like the batter was overbeaten, as the waffle was a bit tough, very sad. otherwise, toast is consistently fantastic!
author: Yelp Y.

description: Kids were dropped off at a movie so my sweetie and I had 2 hours to ourselves...so what to do but go out and eat at a place that isn't necessarily kid friendly.    We found ourselves at TOAST, never been and it IS kid friendly.  The ambiance is great, just a tad bit small but the meal was really great.  Philly cheese steak with a house salad, the dressing was so very tasty.  Definitely would love to try their breakfast but suspect the wait on the weekend may deter us since it is rather small.  Cute neighborhood joint.
author: Maureen T.

description: I kept hearing whispers and murmurs about this place with two locations in 'cool' parts of the city and was in Noe Valley doing errands yesterday around 3:00 pm and stumble upon it by accident.  Opportunity strikes in strange and unexpected ways, so I seized it and walked in and grabbed a menu and immediately liked the place.  It's small but clean, spare and inviting, and I loved the menu, it suggested good food, well prepared so I sat at the counter on a slightly too small stool (hey, I'm a huge guy) and ordered their basic burger with fries and a side of onion rings.  The menu told me they use Niman beef and the exposed stainless kitchen also told me they are meticulous in everything I could see so plainly and I felt confident I was getting fresh, well handled grub at this neat diner.  The spare space has about a dozen two top tables with nice upholstered chairs and there are maybe a dozen counter stools topped in bright red.  Color is gentle and spare and the artwork is various huge slices of toast with painted drawings by a local artist done in the style of the late Al Hirschfeld and they're wonderful.  Simple lighting, expansive, clean windows, a custom neon wall clock and well trained, pleasant servers working with clean, white uniformed kitchen staff served up my order which was perfectly cooked and served.  The burger was cooked just the way I wanted it, and the bun was toasted and the density was just right for the meat and fresh lettuce, tomato, red onion and sliced pickles.  Damn, the tomato's even had the tough, hard to chew center cut out, that's a sweet touch.  The fries are shoestring and house cut as well as blanched before frying which makes a near perfect fry, and the onion rings were addictive and delicious.  The portions are big and the prices are moderate, this place is a gem and I look forward to returning often.  They make shakes and serve Mitchell's Ice cream, a great local plus.  Beer and wine are available and they serve their whole menu from 7:00 AM to 10:00 PM Monday's thru Saturday's and from 7:00 to 5:00 PM on Sunday's.  Credit cards accepted as well as spoiled kids so choose a time when there isn't a Costco like parking lot of custom baby strollers piloted by rude, ignorant and self centered young parents who add to the current crop of arrogant slobs ruining the world with self serving greed.
author: Stu S.

description: Decided to go here for brunch on a Sunday.  Bracing myself for a long wait, I was quite surprised that we only porbably waited for about 15 minutes considering there was about 8 groups ahead of us.  I had the the french toast with fruits...it was ok.  Not bad but nothing great.  My cousin had a tuna melt and garlic fries.  The fries would've been okay if they hadn't used those "pre-choped and bottled" garlic.  The garlic taste wasn't the same.
author: Gia C.

description: Overpriced mediocre food.  They charge a ton for maple syrup on top of the overpriced pancakes.  Nothing special about this place.
author: M C.

description: In general the atmosphere was rather reasonable in that one could easily have a conversation.  However, the food was certainly uninspiring and frankly not appetizing in the least.  Banana walnut pancakes were dry, bland pancakes simply with bananas and walnuts strewn about the plate.  A bowl of fruit was simply an assortment of underripe melon with pineapple.  Needless to say, I shall not venture back for a second meal.
author: Tim S.

description: stale toast yumm. i'll stick with joe's or make breakfast at home. i have bills to pay and can't keep throwing my money away at overpriced chains like toast. service: wants to be something its not, food: price is not inline with what is on offer - nothing unique and not all that good quality. decor: is pretty good - but does not fit in with the street. that's my take. keep walking.
author: Sara J.

description: Breakfast sandwich on an English muffin: Very average. Hash browns: excellent.
author: Jacob K.

description: Wow - this place rocks just as much as the first one on Church street! Went here for breakfast this morning and had the croissant french toast - I must say it was truly amazing. Service was great - what a solid start. Welcome to the neighborhood Toast - great to finally have you here!
author: SF Gal ..

description:
While walking in Noe Valley with a friend from  NYC last sunday, we initially decided to have lunch at Pasta Pomodoro. Upon walking up 24th street ,we noticed Toast and the crazy mob waiting outside to be seated. Glancing into the restaurant thru the all-glass facade our eyes immediately focused on the generous portions of fresh-looking salads and mouth watering plates of golden waffles and fresh fruits including blueberries,raspberries,etc.
           The hostess told us it would be a 30-40 minute wait so we decided to put our name on the waiting list and grab a coffee at Starbucks. Twenty minutes later,my name was called and we were seated at the bar. The restaurant was impeccably clean and the service was prompt and more or less efficient. Ive had my fair share of corned-beef hash and I must say  Toast's hash is amazingly tender and well-seasoned.........delicious. My friend ordered the nutella pancakes and she was not dissapointed. The fresh fruit was  F-R-E-S-H and excellent quality.....fresh raspberries,blueberries and melon. Toast is a no-nonsense breakfast spot that uses fresh ingredients with a presentation of food that is not super sheeshy or over-priced. Very San Francisco nuts and bolts breakfast spot. I'll definetly go back.
author: peter n.

description: It's so great to have a decent new place for casual food in the neighborhood. They have a solid menu for breakfast, brunch, or lunch food. I would be less inclined to go there for dinner. Like the Church location, the service isn't the greatest, but it's not bad either. Given that there are so few lunch/brunch options in the 24th street corridor, it's great to have a new option, and I think Toast is going to attract a lot of business from Savor, whose service seems to decline to new lows every quarter. So far, I've only ordered the Niman Ranch Classic Burger and Fries, and find it to be good tasting and well prepared, and the fries have a nice light crispy feeling. One complaint - I find the menu to be extremely misleading. They make a big deal about serving Niman Ranch meat on the menu, and many of the items do use Niman Ranch meat, but many other items use standard industrial factory farmed meats. I think it's misleading to mix organic and factory meats on the same page. Bottom line: Nothing particularly outstanding about this place, but nothing bad either - a solid, clean, reasonably fast, and tasty option for basic American diner style food.
author: Eater S.

description: okay so i dont get why we need to toast in the same neighborhood.. but hey if you have that kind of money go for it... service was good and food was okay... i had the eggs benedict but it wasnt great! my friend had just a regular bacon and eggs.... you cant go wrong there... the door was open so it was super cold and the tables are way to close together.. rather  liked the fact they had hash browns.. but id rather go to chloe's or basso's for breakfast..
author: Shauna P.

description: This place is a complete joke and a disgrace to Herbs!!!!  The food is crappy at best, way overpriced and the service-horrible.  Its really amazing that people actually eat here but I guess when you're desperate u gotta eat.  If you want to try a real brekfast joint go to Cloes on Church Street.
author: Matt M.

description: every time I see people waiting to eat here I am baffled. Why? It is not cheap, the food is completely uninspired and mediocre. It must be the shiny fixtures
author: Noe K.

description:
i have to agree with some of the other yelpers; service was friendly but slow; my water glass was never refilled; the food was not bad. 

the wait is a bit long for what it is, but such is the case with new places. i'll be back for a late lunch/early dinner.
author: B N.

description: I've been patiently waiting as I constantly walk by this space, finally the construction is finished and Toast has opened.  So glad to have another brunch option on 24th- I'm hoping this will take the wait times down a little bit.  I've been here twice for brunch already.  The wait was not bad-  I found it easy to find the sign in list and was called sooner than expected . The staff is friendly and attentive.  I'm a fan of the scramblers-veggie had a lot more avocado than i expected-not a bad thing, but the real find for me is the fresh fruit- which is far superior to what chloe's calls its fresh fruit option.  It is in fact fresh fruit including seasonal berries that seemed like it could have been carried in from the farmer's market down a couple blocks.  I have also tasted the pancakes which i approve of -but not quite like chloes specials,  the hash browns were nothing special- i'm a sucker for the potatoes at savor.  I think it is a solid option for brunch and will be back to try other meals.
author: Maria F.

description: Stopped in mid-afternoon Saturday for some brunch and loved it. Sat at the counter, watched the ball game and had some great coffee and a truly scrumptious omelette, the one with lox & capers, a bit pricey maybe but friendly staff & a clean non-grungy place to eat has to cost something.
author: I A.

description: Been in Noe Valley for 12 years now... some places come and go and some just blow! It amazes me why so many people line up outside for this overpriced, over crowded non inviting eatery? I make a better breakfast and don't burn the hash browns so much that they hurt when you eat them? Not to mention the poorly designed layout... the counter is so large in depth that the wait staff reach so far to serve people?... you sit so close to the people next to you on the stool that i might as well eat their food too? Tables? What happened to diner booths? Did you half ass the building permits just like your layout? The place is not fun or inviting? sure Herbs was run down but ya could of capitalized on the whole diner theme with new items and a better layout. And my favorite... just last Sunday I get that attitude from a female wait staff when I wanted to sit at the counter and order my favorite burnt hash browns... she told me to sign up for an empty counter? WTF? Everyone outside are waiting for 4 plus seating at tables and I was baffled when I looked at the sign up sheet? Walked the eff out... Toast... do us all a favor... attitude check with the staff, clean up or move out!!! One last note... I'm not the only long term Noewegian that thinks the same... word of mouth goes a long way!?!?!?
author: Jim T.

description: I don't think it's quite as horrible as some of you, but it's definitely not great.  I've ordered for pick-up three or four times and it's okay when I'm in a rush.  Their service needs some major work though.  First time they messed up my order and gave me the Chicken Club instead of Spicy Chicken sandwich.    My friend had a worse experience when they forgot to enter her order into the computer, so it wasn't ready when she got there.  They then tried to convince her that she had called the Church Street location...NEVER blame the customer!!!  When they found her order scrawled on a little pad next to the telephone, there was no apology or offer of a discount at all.  Not even an "Oops, our bad!"  Their side salad is absolutely terrible, and I'm not picky when it comes to salads.  But the lettuce was so limp and there weren't even hints of any veggies in it.  I hate wasting food, but I had to throw the salad in the compost.  The sandwich was good though.  Also, there's a waitress there who really needs to learn how to dress appropriately.  No way would I want to bring my kids in there when she's wearing hot shorts, stripper boots, and a seriously low cut shirt.  So for the service, 1/2 star, and 1 1/2 star for the food.  I hope it gets better, since it's convenient for me.
author: Janie K.
